editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sir Patient Fancy: A COMEDY As it is Acted at the Duke's Theatre.
Written by Mrs. A. BEHN, the Authour of the ROVER.
LONDON, Printed by E. Flesher for Richard Tonson, within Grays-Inn-gate in Grays-Inn-lane, and Iacob Tonson, at the Iudge's Head in Chancery-lane. 1678.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
I Printed this Play with all the impatient haste one ought to do, who would be vindicated from the most unjust and silly aspersion, Woman could invent to cast on Woman; and which only my being a Woman has procured me; That it was Baudy, the least and most Excusable fault in the Men writers, to whose Plays they all crowd, as if they came to no other end then to hear what they condemn in this: but from a Woman it was unnaturall: but how so Cruell an unkindness came into their imaginations I can by no means guess; unless by those whose Lovers by long absence, or those whom Age or Ugliness have rendered a little distant from those things they would fain imagin here — But if such as these durst profane their Chast ears with hearing it over again, or taking it into their serious Consideration in their Cabinets; they would find nothing that the most innocent Virgins can have cause to blush at: but confess with me that no Play either Ancient or Modern has less of that Bug-bear Bawdry in it. Others to show their breeding (as Bays sayes,) cryed it was made out of at least
four French Plays, when I had but a very bare hint from one, the Malad Imagenere, which was given me translated by a Gentleman infinitely to advantage: but how much of the French is in this, I leave to those who do indeed understand it and have seen it at the Court. The Play had no other Misfortune but that of coming out for a Womans: had it been owned by a Man, though the most Dull Unthinking Rascally Scribler in Town, it had been a most admirable Play. Nor does it's loss of Fame with the Ladies do it much hurt, though they ought to have had good Nature and justice enough to have attributed all its faults to the Authours unhappiness, who is forced to write for Bread and not ashamed to owne it, and consequently ought to write to please (if she can) an Age which has given severall proofs it was by this way of writing to be obliged, though it is a way too cheap for men of wit to pursue, who write for Glory, and a way which even I despise as much below me.

div.head: PROLOGUE, Spoken by Mr. BETTERTON.
div.l: WE write not Now as th' Ancient Poets writ▪
For your Applause of Nature, Sense and Wit;
But, like good Tradesmen, what's in fashion vent,
And Cozen you, to give ye all Content.
True Comedy, writ even in Dryden's style,
Will hardly raise your Humours to a smile:
Long did his Sovereign Muse the Scepter sway,
And long with joy you did true Homage pay;
But now, like happy States luxurious grown,
The Monarch Wit unjustly you dethrone,
And a Tyrannick Commonwealth prefer,
Where each small Wit starts up and claims his share;
And all those Lawrels are in pieces torn,
Which did ere while one sacred Head adorn▪
Nay, even the Women, now, pretend to reign,
Defend us from a Poet Joan again:
That Congregation's in a hopefull way
To Heaven, where the Lay-sisters Preach and Pray▪
Oh the great blessing of a little wit,
I've seen an elevated Poet sit
And hear the Audience laugh and clap, yet say,
Gad after all 'tis a damn'd silly Play:
He unconcern'd, crys onely —is it so?
No matter these unwitty things will doe,
When your fine fustian useless Eloquence
Serves but to chime a sleep a drowsie Audience.
Who at the vast Expence of wit would treat,
That might so cheaply please the Appetite?
Such homely fare you're like to find to night,
Our Author
Knows better how to juggle then to write:
Alas! a Poet's good for nothing now,
Vnless he have the knack of conjuring too;
For 'tis beyond all natural sense to guess
How their strange Miracles are brought to pass.
Your Presto Iack be gone, and come again,
With all the Pocus Art of Legerdemain,
Your dancing Tester, Nut-meg and your Cups,
Out-does your Heroes and your Amorous fops▪
And if 〈◊〉 chance to please you, by that rule,
He that writes Wit is much the greater Fool.

row.cell: An old Rich Alderman, and one that fancies himself always Sick.
His Nephew, in Love with Lucretia.
Gallant to the Lady Fancy, a wild young Fellow of a small Fortune.
Son to the Lady Knowell, in Love with Isabella.
A Foolish Devon-shire Knight, design'd to Marry Lucretia.
An Affected Learned Woman, Mother to Lodw. and Isabella.
A Child of 7. years old, Daughter to Sir Patient Fancy.

div.head: ACT the First.
Scene the First. A Roome.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: 'TIS much I owe to fortune, my dear Lucretia, for being so kind to make us Neighbours, where with ease we may continually exchange our Souls and thoughts without the attendance of a Coach, and those other little Formalities that make a business of a visit, it looks so like a Journey I hate it.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Attendance is that Curse to Greatness that confines the Soul, and spoils good Humour; we are free whilst thus alone, and can laugh at the abominable Fopperies of this Town.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And lament the numberless impertinences wherewith they continually plague all young Women of Quality.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Yet these are the pretious things our grave Parents still chuse out to make us happy with, and all for a filthy Jointure, the undeniable argument for our slavery to Fools.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Custom is unkind to our Sex, not to allow us free choice, but we above all Creatures must be forced to endure the formal recommendations of a Parent; and the more insupportable Addresses of an Odious Foppe, whilst the Obedient Daughter stands — thus — with her Hands pinn'd before her, a set
look, few words, and a meine that cries— come marry me; out upon't.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I perceive then what-ever your Father designes, you are resolv'd to love your own way.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thou maist lay thy Maiden-head upon't, and be sure of the misfortune to win.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: My Brother Lodwick's like to be a happy man then.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Faith my dear Lodwick or no body in my heart, and I hope thou art as well resolv'd for my Cozen Leander.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Here's my hand upon't I am, yet there's something sticks upon my Stomack, which you must know.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Spare the Relation, for I have observ'd of late your Mother to have order'd her Eyes with some softness, her mouth endeavouring to sweeten it self into smiles and dimples, as if she meant to recall Fifteen again and give it all to Leander, for at him she throws her Darts.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Is't possible thou shou'dst have perceiv'd it already?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Long since.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: And, now I begin to love him, 'twou'd vex me to see my Mother Marry him, —well I shall never call him Father.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: He'l take care to give himself a better title.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: This Devonshire Knight too who is recommended to my Mother as a fit Husband for me, I shall be so tormented with— My Brother swears he's the pertest unsufferable Fool he ever saw, when he was at my Uncles last Summer he made all his Diversion.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Prethee let him make ours now, for of all Fops your Countrey Fop is the most tolerable Animal; those of the Town are the most unmanagable Beasts in Nature.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: And are the most noysie, keeping Fops?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Keeping begins to be as ridiculous as Matrimony, and is a greater imposition upon the liberty of man, the Insolence and Expence of their Mistresses has almost tir'd out all but the Old and Doting part of man-kind; The rest begin to know their value, and set a Price upon a good shape, a tolerable Face and Mein, —and some there are who have made excellent Bargains for themselves that way, and will flatter ye and gilt ye an Antiquated Lady as artfully as the most experienc'd Miss of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Lord, Lord! what will this World come to, —but this Mother of mine, —Isabella. Sighs,

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Is discreet and vertuous enough, a little too affected, as being the most learned of her Sex.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Methinks to be read in the Arts as they call 'em, is the peculiar Province of the other Sex.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Indeed the men wou'd have us think so, and boast their Learning, and Languages, but if they can find any of our Sex fuller of words, and to so little purpose as some of their Gownmen, I'le be content to change my Petticoats for Pantiloons and go to a Grammar-school.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Oh they'r the greatest Babelards in Nature.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: They call us Easy, and Fond, and charge us with all weakness, but look into their Actions of Love, State, or War, their roughest business, and you shall find 'em sway'd by some who have the luck to find their feables; witness my Father, a man reasonable enough, till drawn away by doting Love and Religion: what a Monster my young Mother makes of him, Flatter'd him first into Matrimony, and now into what sort of Fool or Beast she pleases to make him.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I wonder she does not turn him to Christianity, methinks a Conventicle should ill agree with her humour.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Oh she finds it the only way to secure her from his suspicion, which if she do not e're long give him cause for, I am mistaken in her Humour, — but see your
Enter L. Knowel and Leander. Mother and my Cozen Leander, who seems, poor man, under some great Consternation, for he looks as gravely as a Lay-elder conducting his Spouse from a Sermon.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: Oh fy upon't. See Mr. Fancy where your Cozen and my Lucretia are idling, dii boni, what an insupportable loss of time's this?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Which might be better imploy'd if I might instruct 'em Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p:
Aye Mr. Fancy, in Consultation with the Antients, — Oh the delight of Books! when I was of their age, I always imploy'd my looser hours in reading, —if serious, 'twas Tacitus, Seneca, Plutarch's Morals, or some such useful Author; if in an Humour gay, I was for Poetry, Virgil, Homer, or Tasso, Oh that Love between Renaldo and Armida Mr. Fancy! Ah the Caresses that fair Corcereis gave, and received from the young
Warrier, ah how soft, Delicate and tender! upon my Honour I cannot read them in the Excellence of their Original Language, without I know not what Emotions.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis very well in our Mother tongue Madam.

sp.speaker: La. K.
sp.p: O Faugh Mr. Fancy what have you said, Mother tongue! Can any thing that's great or moving be exprest in filthy English,—I'le give you an Energetical proof Mr. Fancy, observe but Divine Homer in the Grecian Language — Ton d'apamibominus, Prosiphe, Podis Ochus Achilleus! ah how it sounds! which English't dwindles into the most grating stuff: —then the swift Foot Achilles made reply, —oh faugh.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: So now my Mother's in her right Sphere.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Come Mr. Fancy we'le pursue our first design of retiring into my Cabinet and reading a leaf or two in Martiall, I am a little dull and wou'd fain laugh.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Methinks Madam discourse were much better with these young Ladyes. Dear Lucretia find some way to release me. Aside.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh how I hate the impertinance of women, who for the generality have no other knowledge then that of dressing, I am uneasy with the unthinking Creatures.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis much better to be Entertaining a young Lover alone, but I'le prevent her if possible. Aside.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: No, I am for the substantiall pleasure of an Author. Philosophemur! is my Motto, —I'm strangely fond of you Mr. Fancy, for being a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Who Madam I a scholar? the greatest Dunce in Nature, —Malicious Creatures will you leave me to her mercy?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Prethee assist him in his misery, for I am Mudd, and can doe nothing towards it. Aside.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Who my Cozen Leander a Scholar Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Sure He's too much a Gentleman to be a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I Vow Madam he spells worse then a Country Farryer when he Prescribes a Drench.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Then Madam I write the lewdest hand!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Worse then a Politician or a States-man.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: He cannot read it himself when he has done.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Not a word on't Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: This agreement to abuse him, I understand— Aside. —Well then Mr. Fancy, let's to my Cabinet—your hand.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p:
Now shall I be teas'd unmercifully, —I'le waite on you Madam.
Exit Lady. — Find some means to redeem me or I shall be Mad.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hah my dear Isabella here, and without a spy? what a blessed opportunity must I be forc't to lose, for there is just now arriv'd My Sisters Lover, whom I am oblig'd to receive, but if you have a mind to laugh a little—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Laugh! why are you turn'd Buffoon, Tumbler or Presbyterian Preacher.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, but▪ there's a Creature below more ridiculous then either of these.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: For loves sake what sort of Beast is that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir Credulous Easie your new Lover just come to Town Bag and Baggage, and I was going to acquaint my Mother with it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You'l find her well imploy'd with my Cozen Leander.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: A happy opportunity to Free him, but what shall I doe now Brother!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh let me alone to ruine him with my Mother, get you gon, I think I hear him coming, and this apartment is appointed for him.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
Prethee haste then and free Leander, we'l into the Garden.
Exeunt Lucr. and Isab.

div.stage: Enter Sir Credulous in a riding habit, Curry his Groom carrying a Portmantle.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes —tis the Right Worshipfull, I'le to my Mother with the news.
Exit Lod.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Come undoe my Portmantue and Equip me that I may look like somebody before I see the Ladies.—Curry, Thou shalt e'ne remove now Curry from Groom to Footman, for I'le ne're keep Horse more, no, nor Mare neither since my Poor Gillian's departed this life.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Ds diggers, Sir, you have griev'd enough for your Mare in all conscience, think of your Mistress now Sir, and think of her no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Not think of her? I shall think of her whilst I live, poor Fool, that I shall, though I had forty Mistresses!

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p:
Nay to say truth Sir, 'twas a good natur'd Civil beast,
and so she remain'd to her last gasp, for she cou'd never have left this world in a better time, as the saying is, so near her journeys End.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Civil Beast? Why was it Civilly done of her thinkest thou to dye at Branford, when had she liv'd till tomorrow, she had been converted into Mony and have been in my Pocket? for now I am to Marry and live in town, I'le sell off all my Pads; poor Fool, I think she e'ne died for grief I wou'd have sold her.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: 'Twas unlucky to refuse Parson Cuffets wifes money for her Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Aye, and to refuse her another kindness too that shall be nameless which She offer'd me, and which wou'd have given me good luck in horse-flesh too, Zoz I was a modest fool that's truth on't.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: Well well Sir, her time was come you must think, and we are all Mortal as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well 'twas the lovingst titt, —but grass and hay she's gon— where be her shooes Curry?

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: Here Sir, her Skin went for good Ale at Branford.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ah! how often has she carry'd me upon these shooes to Mother Iumbles, thou remember'st her handsome Daughter and what pure Ale she brew'd, between one and t'other my Rent came short home there, but let that pass too, and hang sorrow as thou sayst, I have something else to think on. Takes his things out, lays them upon the Table. And Curry, as soon as I am drest, go you away to St. Clements Church-yard, to Iackson the Cobler there!

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: What your Dog-tutor Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Yes, and see how my whelp proves I put to him last Parlament.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

div.stage: Enter Leander and starts back seeing Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: And ask him what Gamesters come to the Ponds now adays, and what good Dogs.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This is the Beast Lodwick spoke of; how cou'd I laugh were he design'd for any but Lucretia! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
And dost hear, ask him if he have not sold his own Dog Diver with the white Ear, if I can purchase him, and my own Dog prove right, I'le be Duke of Ducking Pond ads zoz.
Sir Cred. dresses himself.
Well, I think I shall be fine anon, he.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: But zo zo Sir, as the saying is, this Suit's a little out of fashion, 'twas made that very year I came to your Worship, which is five Winters and as many Summers.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What then Mun, I never wear it but when I go to be drunk and give my Voice for a Knight o'th' shire, and here at London in Term time, and that but Eight times in Eight Visits to Eight several Ladies to whom I was recommended.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: I wonder that amongst Eight you got not one Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Eight! Zoz I have had Eight score Mun, but the Devil was in 'em, they were all so Forward, that before I cou'd seal and deliver, whip quoth Iethro, they were either all Married to some body else, or run quite away; so that I am resolv'd if this same Lucretia prove not right, I'le e'ne forswear this Town and all their false Wares, amongst which Zoz I believe they vent as many false Wives as any Metropolitan in Christendom, I'l say that for't and a Fiddle for't i'faith, —come give me my Watch out, —so, My Diamond Rings too, so, I think I shall appear pretty well all together Curry, hah?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Like something Monstrously Ridiculous, I'l be sworn.

sp.speaker: Curr.
sp.p: Here's your Purse of broad Gold Sir, that your Grandmother gave you to go a wooing withall, I mean to show Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Aye, for she charged me never to part with it, — so, now for the Ladyes. Shakes his Ribbons.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Leander, what mak'st thou here, like Holy-day Fool gazing at a Mother?
Enter Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Yes, and one I hope I have no great reason to fear.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I am of thy opinion, away, my mother's coming, take this opportunity with my Sister, she's i▪th' Garden, and let me alone with this Fool, for an Entertainment that shall shew him all at once, away—
Exit Lean.

div.stage: Lod. goes in to Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Lodwick, My dear Friend! and little spark of ingenuity! — Zoz mam I'me but just come to Town. Imbrace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis a joyful hearing Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Not so joyful neither Sir, when you shall know Poor Gillian's dead, My little gray Mare, thou knew'st her mun, Zoz 'thas made me as Melancholy as the Drone of a Lancashire Bagpipe, but let that pass, and now we talk of my Mare, Zoz I long to see this Sister of thine.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She'l be with you presently Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: But hark ye, Zoz I have been so often fob'd off in these matters, that between you and I Lodwick if I thought I shou'd not have her, Zoz I'de ne'r lose precious time about her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Right Sir, and to say truth, these Women have so much Contradiction in 'em, that 'tis ten to one but a man fails in the Art of pleasing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Why there's it, — therefore prethee dear Lodwick tell me a few of thy Sisters Humours, and if I fail, —then Hang me Ladies at your door, as the Song says.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why faith she has many odd Humours hard enough to hit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Zoz let'em be as hard as Hercules his Labours in the Vale of Basse, I'le not be frighted from attempting her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, She's one of those fantastick Creatures that must be courted her own way.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Why let's hear her way.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She must be surpris'd with strange Extravagancies wholly out of the Road and Method of common Court-ship.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Shaw, is that all, Zoz I'm the best in Christendom at You're out of the way bus'nesses, — Now do I find the reason of all my ill success, for I us'd one and the same method to all I Courted, whatever their Humours were; Hark ye, prethee give me a hint or two, and let me alone to manage matters.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have just now thought of a way that cannot but take—

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Zoz out with it man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, what if you should represent a Dumb Ambassador from the Blind God of Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: How, a Dumb Ambassador? Zoz man how shall I deliver my Embassy then, and tell her how much I love her, —besides I had a pure speech or two ready by heart, and that will be quite lost. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Phy, phy! how dull you are! why; you shall do it by Signes, and I'le be your Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Why faith this will be pure, I understand you now, Zoz I am old Excellent at Signes, —I vow this will be rare.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It will not fail to do your bus'ness if well manag'd, — but stay, here's my Sister, on your life not a syllable.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: I'le be rackt first, Mum budget, He falls back making Faces and Grimaces. —prethee present me, I long to be at it, sure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sister, I here present you with a worthy Knight, struck dumb with Admiration of your Beauty, but that's all one, he is employ'd Envoy extraordinary from the blind God of Love, and since like his young Master he must be defective in one of his Senses, he chose rather to be Dumb then Blind.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I hope the small Deity is in good health Sir?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And his Mistress Psyche Sir? He smiles and bows and makes Signes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
He sayes that Psyche has been sick of late, but somewhat recovered, and has sent you for a
Looking every word upon Sir Credulous as he makes signes.
token a pair of Jet Bracelets, and a Cambrick Handkerchief of her own spinning, with a Sentence wrought in't; Heart in hand, at thy Command.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Zoz, Lodwick what do you mean? I'me the Son of an Egyptian if I understand thee. Pulls him, he signes to him to hold his peace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come Sir, the Tokens, produce, produce, — How! Faith I am sorry for that with all my heart, He falls back, making damnable Signes. — he sayes — being somewhat put to't on his journey, he was forc't to Pawn the Bracelets for half a Crown, and the handkerchief he gave his Landlady on the Road for a kindness received,—this 'tis when people will be fooling.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why, the Devil's in this Lodwick, for mistaking my Signes thus, hang me if ever I thought of Bracelets or a Handkerchief, or ever received a civility from any Woman breathing, —is he bewitch't trow? Aside.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Lodwick, you are mistaken in the Knight's meaning all this while. Look on him Sir,—do not you guess from that look and wrying of his mouth, that you mistook the Bracelets for Diamond Rings, which he humbly begs, Madam, you would grace with your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ah, now I perceive it plain.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Pox of his Complement. Why this is worse than t'other, — What shall I do in this case? — should I speak and undeceive them, they would swear 'twere to save my Gems: and to part with 'em — Zoz, how simply should I look? — but hang't, when I have married her they are my own again.

div.stage: Gives the Rings and falls back into Grimaces Leander whispers to Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Enough, — Then Sister she has sent you a Purse of her own knitting, full of broad Gold,—

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Broad Gold! why, what a pox does the Man Conjure?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Which Sister faith you must accept of, you see by that Grimace how much 'twill grieve him else.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: A pretty civil way this to Rob a man,—Why Lodwick —why what a Pox will they have no mercy,— Zoz I'le see how far they'l drive the jest.

div.stage: Gives the Gold, and bowes and scrapes and screws.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Say you so Sir? Well I'le see what may be done,—Sister, behold him, and take pity on him, he has but one more humble request to make you, 'tis to receive a Gold Watch which he designs you from himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Cre.
sp.p: Why, how long has this fellow been a Conjurer? for he does deal with the Devil, that's certain,—Lodwick, —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aye do, speak and spoil all, do.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Speak and spoil all quoth he! and the Deuce take me if I am not provok't to't; why, how the Devil should he light slap dash, as they say, upon every thing thus? Well, Zoz, I am resolv'd to give it her, and shame her if she have any conscience in her. Gives his Watch with pitiful Grimaces.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now Sister you must know there's a mystery in this Watch, 'tis a kind of Hieroglyphick that will instruct you how a Married Woman of your Quality ought to live.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How, my Watch Mysteries and Hieroglyphicks! the Devil take me if I knew any such vertues it had.

div.stage: They are all looking on the Watch.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Beginning at Eight, from which down to Twelve you ought to imploy in dressing, till Two at Dinner, till Five in Visits, till Seven at the Play, till Nine i'th' Park, at Ten at Supper
with your Lover, if your Husband be at home, or keep his distance, which he's too well bred not to do, then from Ten to Twelve are the happy hours of the Bergere, those of intire enjoyment.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Say you so? hang me if I shall not go near to think I may chance to be a Cuckold by the shift.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well Sir, what must she do from Twelve till Eight again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh those are the dull Conjugal hours for sleeping with her own Husband, and dreaming of Joys her absent Lover alone can give her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay an she be for sleeping, Zoz, I am as good at that as she can be for her heart, or snoring either.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I have done; Sir Credulous has a dumb Oration to make you by way of farther Explanation.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A dumb Oration! Now do I know no more how to speak a dumb Speech than the Dog.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Oh I love that sort of Eloquence extreamly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I told you this would take her.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay, I know your silent Speeches are incomparable, and I have such a Speech in my head. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Postures, your Postures, begin Sir.

div.stage: He puts himself into a ready Posture as if he would speak, but onely makes faces.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
Sir, My Lady desires to speak with you.
To Lean.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'le wait on her,—a Devil on't.—

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I have command to bring you Sir, instantly.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This is ill luck Madam, I cannot see the Farce out, I'le wait on you as soon as my good fortune will permit me.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: He's going to my Mother, dear Isabella let's go and hinder their discourse: Farewel Sir Ambassador, pray remember us to Psyche, not forgetting the little Blind Archer, ha ha ha, —

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
So, I have undone all, they are both gone, slown I protest; Why what a Devil ail'd'em? now have I been dumb all this while to no purpose, you too never told her my meaning right; as I hope to breath, had any but your self done this, I
should have sworn by Helicon and all the rest of the Devils, you had had a design to have abus'd me, and cheated me of all my Movables too.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What a hopefull project was here defeated by my mistake! but Courage Sir Credulous, I'le put you in a way shall fetch all about again.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Say you so? ah dear Lodwick let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, you shall this night give your Mistress a Serenade.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How! a Serenade!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, but it must be perform'd after an Extravagant manner, none of your dull Amorous night-walking noises so familiar in this Town, Lucretia loves nothing but what's great and Extravagant, and passes the reach of Vulgar practice.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What think you then of a silent Serenade? Zoz say but the word and it shall be done man, let me alone for Frolicks i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A silent one? no that's to wear a good Humour to the stumps; I wou'd have this want for no noise, the Extreams of these two addresses will set off one another.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Say you so? what think you then of the Bagpipe, Tongs and Gridiron, Cat-calls and loud sounding Cymballs?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Naught, naught, and of known use, you might as well treat her with Viols and Flute-doux, which were enough to disoblige her for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why, what think you then of the King of Bantam's own Musick?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How! the King of Bantam's Musick!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Aye Sir, the King of Bantam's: a Friend of mine had a Present sent him from thence, a most unheard of curiosity I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That, that by all means Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well, I'll go borrow 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You must provide your self of a Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Song! hang't 'tis but rummaging the Play-Books, stealing thence is Lawfull Prize — Well Sir Cred. your servant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I hope 'twill be ridiculous enough, and then the Devil's in't if it do not doe his Business with my Mother, for she hates
all impertinent Noises but what she makes her self. She's now going to make a Visit to your Uncle, purposely to give me an opportunity to Isabella.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: And I'me ingag'd to wait on her thither, she designe to carry the Fiddles too, he's Mad enough already, but such a Visit will fit him for Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No matter, for you have all a lewd hand with him; between his continual imaginary sickness, and perpetual Physick, a man might take more Pleasure in an Hospital. What the Devil did he marry a young Wife for? and they say a handsome creature too.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: To keep up his Title of Cuckold I think, for she has beauty enough for temptation, and no doubt makes the right use on't: wou'd I cou'd know it, that I might prevent her cheating my Uncle longer to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She'll be cunning enough for that, if she have wit: but now thou talk'st of intrigues, when didst see Wittmore? that Rogue has some lucky Haunt which we must find out.— But my Mother expects your attendance, I'le go seek my Sister, and make all the Interest there I can for you, whilst you pay me in the same Coin to Isabella. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Trust my Friendship— Exeunt severally.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I. A Garden.
div.stage: Enter Lady Fancy, Wittmore and Maundy.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: ENough my Charming Mistriss, you've set my Soul at Peace, and chas'd away those Fears and Doubts my Jealousy created there.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p:
Mr. Wittmore's satisfy'd of your constancy Madam, though had I been your Ladyship, I should have given him a
more substantiall Proof, which you might yet doe, if you wou'd make handsom use of your time.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Maundy advises well my Dearest, let's withdraw to yonder Covert Arbour, whose kind shades will secure us a happiness that Gods might envy. Offers to lead her out.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: I dare not for the world, Sir Patient is now asleep, and 'tis to those few Minutes we are oblig'd for this injoyment, which shou'd Love make us transgress, and he shou'd wake and surprize us, we were undone for ever; no let us imploy this little time we have in consulting how we may be often happy, and securely so: oh how I languish for the dear opportunity!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And cou'd you guess what torments I have suffer'd in these few Fatal Months that have divided us, thou woud'st pity me.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: —but to our business; for though I am yet unsuspected by my Husband, I am eternally plagu'd with his company, he's so fond of me, he scarce gives me time to write to thee, he waits on me from room to room, hands me in the Garden, shoulders me in the Belcony, nay does the office of my women, dresses and undresses me, and does so smirk at his handy-work! in fine, dear Wittmore, I am impatient till I can have less of his company, and more of thine.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Does he never goe out of Town?

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Never without me.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nor to Church?

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: To a meeting-house you mean, and then too carries me, and is as vainly proud of me as of his Rebellious opinion, for his Religion means nothing but that, and Contradiction; which I seem to like too, since 'tis the best cloak I can put on to cheat him with.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Right my fair Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: But dear Wittmore, there's nothing so Comicall as to hear me Cant, and even cheat those knaves the Preachers themselves that delude the Ignorant Rabble.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What Miracles cannot your Eyes and Tongue perform!

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p:
Judge what a fine life I lead the while, to be set up with an old Formal Doating sick Husband, and a Herd of snivelling grinning Hypocrites that call themselves the teaching Saints, who under pretence of securing me to the number
of their Flock, do so sneer upon me, pat my Breasts and cry, fy, fy upon this fashion of tempting Nakedness.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Dear Creature, how cou'd we laugh at thy new way of living, had we but some minutes allow'd us to injoy that pleasure alone.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Think, dear Wittmore think, Maundy and I have thought over all our devices to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Pox on't I'me the dullest Dog at Plotting, Thinking, in the world, I should have made a damnable Ill Town Poet; has he quite left off going to the Change?

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Oh, he's grown Cautiously rich, and will venture none of his substantiall stock in transitory Traffick.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Has he no Mutinous Caball, nor Coffee-houses, where he goes religiously to consult the wellfare of the Nation?

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: His imagin'd sickness has made this their Rendesvouz.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: When he goes to his blind Devotion, cannot you pretend to be sick? that may give us at least two or three opportunities to begin with.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Oh! then I should be plagu'd with continual Physick and Extempore Prayer till I were sick indeed.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Damn the Humorous Coxcombe and all his Family, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Not all, for he has a Daughter that has good Humour, Wit, and Beauty enough to save her, — stay — that has jogg'd a thought as the learned say, which must jogg on, till the motion have produc't something worth my thinking. —

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Ad's me here's danger near, our Scout comes in such hast.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Roger, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My Master, Madam, is risen from sleep, and is come into the Garden, — See Madam he's here.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: What an unlucky accident was this?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What shall I do? 'tis too late to obscure my self.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: He see's you already through the Trees, — here — keep your distance, your Hat under your Arm, so, be very Ceremonious whilst I settle a demure Countenance.—

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Well, there never came good of Lovers that were given to too much talking; had you been silently kind all this while, you had been willing to have parted by this time.

div.stage: Enter Sir Patient in a Night-gown, reading a Bill.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hum, — Twelve Purges for this present Ianuary, — as I take it, good Mr. Doctor, I took but Ten in all December, — by this Rule I am sicker this Month than I was the last, — and good Master Apothecary methinks your Prizes are somewhat to high, at this rate no body wou'd be sick. — Here Roger, see it paid however,—Ha, hum. Sees 'em and starts back. What's here, my Lady Wife entertaining a lewd fellow of the Town? a flaunting Cap and Feather Blade?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Sir Patient cannot now be spoken with. But Sir, that which I was going just now to say to you, was, that it would be very convenient in my opinion to make your addresses to Isabella, — 'twill give us opportunities. Aside We Ladies love no imposition, this is Counsel my Husband perhaps will not like, but I would have all Women chuse their Man, as I have done, — my dear Wittmore. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I profess ingenuously an excellent good Lady this of mine, tho' I do not like her Counsel to the young man, whom I perceive would be a suiter to my Daughter Isabella.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Madam, should I follow my inclinations, I should pay my vows no where but there, — but I am inform'd Sir Patient is a man so positively resolv'd. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: That you should love his Wife. Aside.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And I'le comply with that resolve of his, and neither Love nor Marry Isabella, without his Permission, and I doubt not but I shall by my respects to him gain his consent, — to Cuckold him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I profess ingenuously a very discreet young man.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But Madam, when may I promise my self the satisfaction of coming again? For I'me impatient for the sight and enjoyment of the fair person I love.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Sir, You may come at night, and something I will doe by that time shall certainly give you that access you wish for.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: May I depend upon that happiness?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh, doubt not my power over Sir Patient.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My Lady Fancy, you promise largely.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Sir Patient here?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A Devil on him, wou'd I were well off, now must I dissemble, profess, and lye most confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, your Servant, — My Lady Fancy, your Ladiship is well entertain'd I see, have a care you make me not Jealous, my Lady Fancy.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Indeed I have given you cause Sir Patient, for I have been entertaining a Lover, and one you must admit of too.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Say you so, my Lady Fancy? — Well Sir, I am a man of Reason, and if you shew me good causes why, can bid you welcom, for I do nothing without Reason aud Precaution.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Sir I have. —

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I know what you wou'd say Sir, few words denoteth a wise head, — you wou'd say that you have an ambition to be my Son in Law.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: You guess most right Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I'le warrant I'le read a man as well as the best, I have studied it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Now Invention help me or never.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Your Name I pray? Putting off his Hat gravely at every word.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Fain-Love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Good Mr. Fain-Love, your Countrey?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Yorkshire, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What, not Mr. Fain-Love's Son of Yorkshire, who was Knighted in the good days of the late Lord Protector?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: The same Sir, — I am in, but how to come off again the Devil take me if I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: He was a man of admirable Parts, believe me, a notable head-piece, a Publick-spirited Person, and a good Commonwealths man, that he was, on my word, — Your Estate Sir, I pray? Hat off.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I have not impair'd it Sir, and I presume you know its value? For I'me a Dog if I doe. —

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
O' my word 'tis then considerable Sir, for he left but one Son, and Fourteen hundred Pounds per annum, as I take it, which Son I hear is lately come from Geneva, whither he was
sent for vertuous Education. I am glad of your Arrival Sir, — Your Religion I pray?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: You cannot doubt my Principles, Sir, since educated at Geneva.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Your Father was a discreet Man, ah Mr. Fain-love, he and I have seen better dayes, and wish we cou'd have foreseen these that are arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: That he might have turn'd honest in time, he means, before he had purchas'd Bishops Lands.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sir, You have no Place, Office, Dependance or Attendance at Court I hope?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: None Sir. — Wou'd I had, — so you were hang'd.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Nay Sir, you may believe, I knew his Capacities and Abilities before I would encourage his Addresses.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My Lady Fancy, you are a discreet Lady; — Well I'le marry her out of hand to prevent Mr. Lodwick's hopes, for tho' the young man may deserve well, that mother of his I'le have nothing to do with, since she refused to marry my Nephew. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Sir Father, here's my Lady Knowell and her Family come to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How! her whole Family! I am come to keep open House; very fine, her whole Family! she's Plague enough to mortify any good Christian, — tell her, my Lady and I am gon forth; tell her any thing to keep her away.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Shou'd I tell a lye Sir Father, and to a Lady of her Quality?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Her Quality and she are a Couple of impertinent things, which are very troublesome, and not to be indur'd I take it.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Sir, we shou'd bear with things we do not love sometimes, 'tis a sort of trial Sir, a kind of mortification fit for a good Christian.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why, what a notable talking Baggage is this! How came you by this Doctrine?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I remember, Sir, you Preach'd it once to my Sister, when the old Alderman was the Text, whom you exhorted her to marry, but the wicked Creature made ill use on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Go your way for a Prating Huswife, go, and call your Sister hither. [Exit Fanny.] — Well I'me resolv'd to leave this Town, nay, and the World too, rather than be tormented thus.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: What's the matter Dear, thou dost so fret thy self?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: The matter! my house, my house is besieged with impertinence, the intolerable Lady, Madam Romance, that walking Library of Profane Books is come to visit me.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: My Lady Knowell?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Yes, that Lady of eternal noise and hard words.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis with pain I am oblig'd to be civil to her, but I consider her Quality, her Husband was too an Alderman your friend, and a great Ay and no Man i'th' City, and a painful promoter of the good Cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But she's a Fop, my Lady Fancy, and ever was so; an idle conceited she Fop, and has vanity and tongue enough to debauch any Nation under Civil Government: but, Patience, thou art a vertue, and Affliction will come, — Ah I'me very sick, alas I have not long to dwell amongst the Wicked, Oh, oh. — Roger, is the Doctor come?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No Sir, but he has sent you a small draught of a Pint, which you are to take and move upon't.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah, — Well I'le in and take it; — Ah — Sir, I crave your Patience for a moment, for I design you shall see my Daughter, I'le not make long work on't Sir, alas I would dispose of her before I die, Ah, — I'le bring her to you Sir, Ah, Ah. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: He's always thus when visited, to save charges, — But how dear Wittmore cam'st thou to think of a Name and Countrey so readily?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Egad I was at the height of my invention, and the Alderman civilly and kindly assisted me with the rest; but how to undeceive him,—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Take no care for that, in the mean time you'l be shrewdly hurt to have the way laid open to our enjoyment, and that by my Husbands procurement too: but take heed dear Wittmore, whilst you only design to feign a Courtship, you do it not in good earnest.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Unkind Creature!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I wou'd not have you indanger her heart neither: for thou hast Charmes will do't. — Prethee do not put on thy best looks, nor speak thy softest language; for if thou dost, thou canst not fail to undoe her.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Well my pretty Flatterer, to free her heart and thy suspicions, I'le make such aukward Love as shall perswade her, however she chance to like my Person, to think most lewdly of my parts, — But 'tis fit I take my leave, for if Lodwick or Leander see me here, all will be ruin'd, death I had forgot that.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Leander's seldom at home, and you must time your Visits: but see Sir Patient's return'd, and with him your new Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Here's my Daughter Isabella, Mr. Fain-love: she'l serve for a Wife, Sir, as times goe; but I hope you are none of those, —Sweet-heart — this Gentleman I have design'd you, he's rich and young, and I am old and sickly, and just going out of the world, and would gladly see thee in safe hands.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: He has been just going this twenty Years. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Therefore I command you to receive the tenders of his Affection.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Sir Father, my Lady Knowell's in the Garden.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: My Dear, we must go meet her in decency.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A hard case a man cannot be sick in quiet. —

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Husband, and that not Lodwick! Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p:
Now Foppery assist to make me very ridiculous. — Death she's very pretty and inviting, what an insensible Dog shall I be counted to refuse the enjoyment of so fair, so new a Creature, and who is like to be thrown into my Arms too whether I will or not? — but Conscience and my vows to the fair Mother: No I will be honest, — Madam, — as Gad shall save me, I'me the Son of a Whore, if you are not the most Bell Person I ever saw, and if I be not damnably in love with
you, but a pox take all tedious Courtship, I have a free-born and generous Spirit, and as I hate being confin'd to dull cringing, whining, flattering, and the Devil and all of Foppery, so when I give an heart I'me an Infidel, Madam, if I do not love to do't frankly and quickly, that thereby I may oblige the Beautiful receiver of my Vows, Protestations, Passions, and Inclination.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You're wonderfull ingaging Sir, and I were an Ingrate not to facilitate a return for the Honour you are pleas'd to do me.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
Upon my Reputation, Madam, you're a civil well-bred Person, you have all the Agreemony of your Sex, La Bell Talie, la Boon Mien, & reparteét bien, and are tout one toore, as I'me a Gentleman, fort agreeable. — If this do not please your Lady, and Nauseate her, the Devil's in 'em both for unreasonable Women. —
To Maund.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Gemini Sister, does the Gentleman Conjure?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I know not, but I'me sure I never saw a more affected Fop.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Oh a damnable impertinent Fop, 'tis pity, for he's a proper Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Well if I do hold out, Egad I shall be the bravest young fellow in Christendome: but Madam, I must kiss your hand at present, I have some Visits to make, Devoirs to pay, necessities of Gallantry only, no Love ingagement by Iove Madam, it is sufficient I have given my Parole to your Father to do him the honour of my Alliance; and an unnecessary Jealousie will but disoblige Madam your slave — Death these Rogues will see me and I'me undone. — Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lady Fancy, Lady Knowell, Sir Credulous and Lucr. with other women and men.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: Isabella, your servant, Madam, being sensible of the insociable and solitary life you lead, I have brought my whole Family to wait on your Ladyship, and this my Son in Futuro, to kiss your hands, I beseech your Ladyship to know him for your humble servant: my Son and your Nephew Madam are coming, with the Musick too, we mean to pass the whole day with your Ladyship: —and see they are here.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick pulling in Wittmore, Leander with them,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay since we have met thee so luckily, you must back with us.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: You must excuse me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: We'le show ye two or three fine women.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Death these Rogues will ruine me— but I have business Gentlemen that—

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: That must not hinder you from doing deeds of Charity, we are all come to teaze my Uncle, and you must assist at so good a work—come gad thou shalt make love to my Aunt, — I wou'd he wou'd effectually. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now I think on't, what the Devil dost thou make here?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Here? — oh Sir—a— I have a design upon the Alderman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Upon his handsome Wife thou meanest? ah Rogue!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Faith no,—a—'tis to—borrow Mony of him, and as I take it Gentlemen you are not fit persons for a man of Credit to be seen with, I pass for a graver man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Well Sir, take your Course—but egad he'le sooner lend thee his wife than his Money.
Ex. Witt. they come in.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Aunt I have taken the boldness to bring a Gentleman of my aquaintance to kiss your Ladiships hands.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Thy Aunt! —death she's very handsom, —Madam your most humble servant.
Kisses the La. Fan.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Prethee imploy this Fool that I may have an opportunity to entertain thy Sister.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir Credulous, what not a word? not a Complement? hah— be brisk man, be gay and witty, talk to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Talk to 'em? why what shall I say to 'em?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Any thing so it be to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay Sir, let me alone for that matter—but who are they prethee?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why that's my Lady Fancy, and that's her Daughter in Law, salute 'em Man.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Fair Lady, — I do protest and vow, you are the most beautifull of all Mothers in Law, and the World cannot produce your equall.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The Rogue has but one method for all Addresses.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh absurd! this Sir is the beautifull Mother in Law.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Most Noble Lady, I cry you mercy,
Enter Sir Pat. Then Madam as the Sun amongst the Stars, or rather as the Moon not in conjunction with the Sun but in her opposition, when one rises the other sets, or as the Vulgar call it Full moon—I say as the Moon is the most beautifull of all the sparkling lights, even so are you the most accomplisht Lady under the Moon— and Madam, I am extreamly sensible of your Charms and Celestial Graces.
To Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pat.
sp.p: Why this is abominable and insupportable.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I find Sir, you can talk to purpose when you begin once.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to say so, Noble Lady; but I must needs say, I am not the worst bred Gentleman for a Country Gentleman that ever you saw, for you must know incomparable Lady that I was at the University three years, and there I learnt my Logick and Rhethorick, whereby I became excellent at Repartee, sweet Lady. As for my Estate, my Father dy'd since I came of Age, and left me a small younger Brothers Portion, dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: A younger Brothers Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha ha, I know what you wou'd infer from that now; but you must know delicious Lady, that I am all the Children my Father had.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Witty I protest.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay Madam when I set on't I can be witty.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Cruel Lucretia leave 'em, and let us snatch this opportunity to talk of our own affairs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: For you must know bright Lady, though I was pleas'd to rally my self, I have a pretty competent Estate of about 3000 l. a year, and am to marry Madam Lucretia.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: You're a happy man Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Not so happy neither, inestimable Lady, for I lost the finest Mare yesterday—but let that pass, were you never in Devonshire Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Never Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Introth and that's pitty sweet Lady, for if you lov'd Hawking, Drinking, and Whoring, —oh Lord, I mean Hunting,
i'faith there be good fellows wou'd keep you company Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: This is a Plot upon me, a meer Plot. — My Lady Fancy, be tender of my reputation, Foppery's catching, and I had as lieve be a Cuckold as Husband to a vain Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Zoz, and that may be as you say Noble Sir. Lady pray what Gentleman's this—Noble Sir, I am your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh cry you mercy Sir. walks away.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No offence dear Sir I protest, 'slife I believe 'tis the Master of the house, he look't with such authority —why who cares, let him look as big as the four Winds, East, West, North, and South, I care not this,—therefore, I Beg your Pardon Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Pray spare your Hat and Legs Sir, till you come to Court, they are thrown away i'th' City.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O Lord dear Sir, 'tis all one for that, I value not a Leg nor an Arm amongst Friends, I am a Devonshire Knight Sir all the world knows, a kind of Country Gentleman, as they say, and am come to Town to Marry my Lady Knowells Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I'm glad on't Sir. walks away, he follows.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: She's a deserving Lady Sir, if I have any Judgment, and I think I understand a Lady Sir in the right Honourable way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Well Sir, that is to say you have been marryed before Sir, and what's all this to me good Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Marryed before incomparable Sir! not so neither, for there's difference in men Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Right, Sir, for some are Wits, and some are Fools!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: As I hope to breath 'twas a saying of my Grandmothers, who us'd to tell me Sir, that bought Wit was best. I have brought money to Town for a small purchase of that kind, for Sir, I wou'd fain set up for a Country Wit—Pray Sir where live the Poets? for I wou'd fain be acquainted with some of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sir I do not know, nor do I care for Wits and Poets. Oh this will kill me quite, I'l out of Town immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But Sir, I mean your Fine railing Bully Wits, that have Vineger, Gall and Arsenick in 'em as well as Salt and Flame and Fire and the Devil and all.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh defend me! and what is all this to me Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh Sir, they are the very Soul of Entertainment, and Sir, it is the prettiest sport to hear 'em rail and baule at one another— Zoz wou'd I were a Poet.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I wish you were, since you are so fond of being rail'd at — if I were able to beat him I would be much angry — but Patience is a Vertue, and I will into the Country.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: 'Tis all one case to me dear Sir, —but I should have the pleasure of railing again, cum privilegio, I love sighting with those pointless Weapons— Zoz Sir, you know if we men of quality fall out— (for you are a Knight I take it) why there comes a Challenge upon it, and ten to one some body or other is run through the Gills, why a pox on't I say this is very damnable, give me Poets Licence.—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Take him off in pity.
To Leander.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Indeed Railing is a Coin only currant among the Poets— Sir Credulous.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh blest deliverance—what a profane wretch is here, and what a lewd world we live in —oh London, London, how thou aboundest in Iniquity, thy Young men are debaucht, thy Virgins defloured, and thy Matrons all turn'd Bawds! my Lady Fancy, this is not company for you I take it, let us fly from this vexation of spirit on the never-failing wings of discretion.—

div.stage: Going to lead Lady Fancy off— the Lady Knowell speaking to Isabella all this while.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: How! marry thee to such a Fop sayest thou? oh egregious!—as thou lovest Lodwick let him not know his name, it will be dangerous, let me alone to evade it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I know his fiery temper too well to trust him with the secret.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Hark ye Sir, and do you intend to doe this horrible thing?—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What thing, my Lady Knowell?

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Why to marry your Daughter Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pat.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: To a beastly town Fool? Monstrum horrendum!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: To any Fool, except a Fool of your Race, of your Generation.—

sp.speaker: L.K.
sp.p:
How! a Fool of my Race, my Generation! I know thou meanest my son, thou contumelious Knight, who let me tell thee,
shall marry thy Daughter invito te, that is, (to inform thy obtuse understanding) in spight of thee, yes shall marry her, though she inherits nothing but thy dull Enthusiasmes, which had she been legitimate she had been possest with.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh abominable! you had best say, she is none of my Daughter, and that I was a Cuckold.—

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: If I should Sir, it would not amount to Scandalum Magnatum, I'le tell thee more; thy whole Pedigree, —And yet for all this Lodwick shall marry your Daughter, and yet I'le have none of your Nephew.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Shall he so, my Lady Knowell? I shall go near to outtrick your Ladyship for all your Politick Learning. 'Tis past the Canonical hour as they call it, or I wou'd marry my Daughter instantly, I profess we ne're had good daies since these Canonicall Fopperies came up again, meer Popish tricks to give our Children time for disobedience, —the next Justice wou'd ha' serv'd turn, and have done the business at any hour, but Patience is a Vertue—Roger, go after Mr. Fain-love, and tell him I wou'd speak with him instantly.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Come come Ladies, we lose fleeting time, upon my Honour we doe, for Madam as I said I have brought the Fiddles, and design to Sacrifice the intire Evening to your Ladyships Diversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Incomparable Lady, that was well thought on, Zoz, I long to be jigging.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Fiddles, Good Lord! why what am I come to! —Madam I take it, Sir Patient Fancies Lady is not a proper Person to make one at immodest Revellings, and Profane Masqueradings.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Why? ah 'tis very true Sir, but we ought not to offend a Brother that is weak, and consequently a Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: An Excellent Lady this, but she may be corrupted, Ah she may fall, I will therefore without delay carry her from this wicked Town.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Come come Gentlemen, let's in, Mr Fancy you must be my man—Sir Credulous come, and you sweet Sir, come Ladies, — Nunc est saltandum, &c. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Patient as before, Lady, Fancy, Wittmore, Maundy, and Roger with things.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Maundy fetch my Cloaths, I'll dress me and out of Town instantly —perswade me not. [To Witt.] Roger, is the Coach ready Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Yes Sir, with four horses.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Out of Town! oh I'm undone then, there will be no hopes of ever seeing Wittmore. [Aside.] —Maundy oh help me to contrive my stay, or I'm a dead Woman. —Sir, sure you cannot goe and leave your affairs in Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Affairs! what Affairs?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Why your Daughter's Marriage Sir, —and—Sir, — not Sir but that I desire of all things in the World the blessing of being alone with you, far from the noise and lewd disorders of this filthy Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Most excellent Woman! ah thou art too good for sinfull Man, and I will therefore remove thee from the temptations of it—Maundy, my Cloaths—Mr. Fain-love, I will leave Isabella with my Lady Fidget my Sister, who shall to morrow see you married to prevent farther inconveniences.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Madam, I have a design, which considering his Spleen, must this time doe our business—'tis— [Whispers.]

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
I like it well, about it instantly, hah—
Ex. Maundy. alas Sir, —what ails your Face? good Heav'n—look Roger.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My Face! why what ails my Face! hah! —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: See Mr. Fain-love, oh look on my dear, is he not strangely alter'd?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Most wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Alter'd, hah—why where, why how alter'd? —hah, Alter'd say you?—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Lord how wildly he stares!

sp.speaker: Sir. Pa.
sp.p: Hah, stare, —wildly? —

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Are you not very sick Sir?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Sick! oh heavens forbid — how does my dearest Love?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Me thinks I feel my self not well o'th' suddain—ah— a kind of shivering seizes all my Limbs, —and am I so much chang'd.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: All over Sir, as big again as you were, —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Your Face is Frightfully blown up, and your dear Eyes just starting from your head, oh I shall sound with the apprehension on't.
falls into Wittmore's Armes.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My head and Eyes so big say you, —oh I am wonderous sick o'th' suddain, — all over say you — oh oh — Ay I perceive it now, my Senses fail me too.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: How Sir, your Senses fail you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: That's a very bad sign, believe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh Ay, for I can neither feel, nor see this mighty growth you speak off. falls into a Chair with great signes of disorder.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Alas I'm sorry for that Sir.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sure 'tis impossible, I'll run and fetch a Glass Sir. Offers to goe.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh stay, I wou'd not for the world he should see what a Monster he is, — and is like to be before to Morrow. Aside.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'll sit him with a Glass — I'll warrant ye it shall advance our design.

div.stage: Enter Maundy with the Cloaths, she starts.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Good Heav'n what ailes you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh — oh —'tis so.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Lord how he's swoln? see how his Stomach struts?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah 'tis true, though I perceive it not.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Not perceive it Sir! put on your Cloaths and be convinc't—try 'em Sir. She pulls off his Gown and puts on his Doublet and Coat, which come not near by a handfull or more.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah it needs not, —mercy upon me— falls back. I'me lost, I'm gone, Oh man what art thou, but a Flower? I am Poyson'd, this talking Ladies breath's infectious; methought I felt the contagion steal into my heart; send for my Physicians and if I die, I'le swear She's my Murtherer, oh see see, how my trembling increases, oh hold my Limbs, I die.—

div.stage: Enter Roger with a Magnifying Glass, shews him the Glass; he looks in it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I'le warant I'le show his Face as big as a Bushel. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh, oh, — I'me a dead man, have me to bed, I die away, undress me instantly, send for my Physicians, I'me Poyson'd, my Bowels burn, I have within an Aetna, They carry him out in a Chair. My Brains run round, Nature within me reels.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And all the drunken Universe does run on wheels. ha ha ha.
Ah my dear Creature, how finely thou hast brought him to his journies end!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: There was no other way but this to have secur'd my happiness with thee, there needs no more then that you come anon to the Garden back-gate, where you shall find admittance, — Sir Patient is like to lie alone to night.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Till then 'twill be a Thousand Ages.

sp.speaker: La Fa.
sp.p: At Games of Love Husbands to cheat is fair, 'Tis the Gallant we play with on the square. Exeunt severally.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Scene draws off and discovers Lady Knowell, Isabella, Lucretia, Lodwick, Leander, Wittmore, Sir Credulous, Other Men and Women, as going to Dance.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: COme one Dance more, and then I think we shall have sufficiently teaz'd the Alderman, and 'twill be time to part.—Sir Credulous, where's your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Within a mile of an Oak, dear Madam, I'le warrant you,— well, I protest and vow, sweet Lady, you dance most
Nobly, — Why, you Dance— like — like a — like a Hasty Pudding before Iove.
They Dance some Antick, or Rustick-Antick. Lodwick speaking to Isabella.

lg.l: Whil'st from the fair Nymphs Eyes apace
Another Stream o'reflow'd her Beautious Face.
Ah happy Nymph, said she, that can
So little value that false Creature man.
Oft the persidious things will cry,
Alass they burn, they bleed, they dye;
But if they're absent half a day,
Nay, let 'em be but one poor hour away,
No more they dye, no more complain,
But like unconstant wretches live again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, have you consider'd of that business yet Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What business?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Of giving me admittance to night.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And may I trust your honesty?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh doubt me not, my Mother's resolv'd it shall be a match between you and I, and that very consideration will secure thee, besides who wou'd first sully the Linnen they mean to put on?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Away here's my Mother.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Madam I beg your pardon for my absence, the effects of my Obedience, not Will; but Sir Patient is taken very Ill o'th' suddain, and I must humbly intreat your Ladiship to retire, for rest is onely essential to his recovery.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: Congruously spoken upon my Honour. Oh the impudence of this Fellow your Ladyships Husband, to espouse so fair a person only to make a Nurse of!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Alas Madam!—

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: A slave, a very houshold Drudg, — Oh faugh, come, never grieve, — for Madam, his Disease is nothing but imagination, a Melancholy which arises from the Liver, Spleen, and Membrane call'd Mesenterium, the Arabians name the distemper Myrathial, and we here in England Hypochondriacal Melancholy; I cou'd prescribe a most potent Remedy, but that I am loth to stir the envy of the College.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Really Madam I believe, —

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: But as you say Madam, we'l leave him to his repose, pray do not grieve too much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Death, wou'd I had the consoleing her, 'tis a charming Woman!

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: Mr. Fancy your hand; Madam your most faithful Servant, — Lucretia, come Lucretia — your Servant Ladies and Gentlemen. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: A Devil on her, wou'd the nimbleness of her Ladyships Tongue were in her Heels, she wou'd make more hast away▪ oh I long for the blest minute. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Isabella, shall I find admittance anon?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: On fair conditions.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Trust my Generosity,— Madam your Slave. — Exit.

div.stage: To La. Fa. gazing on her, goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Madam, I wou'd say something of your Charms and Celestial Graces, but that all praises are as far below you, as the Moon in her Opposition is below the Sun,—and so Luscious Lady, I am yours, — now for my Serenade, —
Exeunt all but La. Fa. and Maundy.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Maundy, have you commanded all the Servants to Bed?

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Yes Madam, not a Mouse shall stir, and I have made ready the Chamber next the Garden for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Then there needs no more but that you wait for Wittmore's coming to the Garden Gate, and take care no lights be in the House for fear of Eyes.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Madam I understand Lovers are best by dark, and shall be diligent, the Doctor has secur'd Sir Patient by a sleeping Pill, and you are onely to expect your approaching happiness.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Leander raise your Soul above that little trifle Lucretia, — cannot you guess what better Fate attends you? — fie, — how dull you are! — must I instruct you in plain rightdown termes? — and tell you — that I propose you Master of my fortune? — now possibly you understand me.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I wish I did not Madam,
Unless I'de vertue to deserve the Bounty;
I have a Thousand faults Dissimulation hides,
Inconstant, wild, debauch'd as youth can make me.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: All that will not do your business.— Aside.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.l: Yet you wou'd have my Daughter take you with all these faults, they're vertues there, but to the name of Mother, they all turn retrograde, I can endure a man
As wild and as inconstant as she can,
I have a Fortune too that can support that Humour,
That of Lucretia does depend on me,
And when I please is nothing;
I'me far from Age or Wrinkles, can be Courted
By Men as gay and youthful as a new Summer's morn,
Beauteous as the first Blossoms of the Spring
Before the common Sun has kiss'd their sweets away,
If with salacious appetites I lov'd,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Faith Madam I cou'd wish, —

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.l: That I were but Fifteen? but—
If there be inequality in years,
There is so too in Fortunes, that might add
A Lustre to my Eyes, Charms to my Person,
And make me fair as Venus, young as Hebe.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Madam you have enough to ingage any unconquer'd heart, but 'twas, I thought, with your allowance I dispos'd of mine, and 'tis a heart that knows not how to change.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p:
Then 'tis a foolish unambitious heart, unworthy of the Elevation it has not Glorious Pride enough to aim at:—
Farewell Sir, — when you are wiser, you may find admittance. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Stay Madam. —

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: For what? to hear your Penitence? Forgive me Madam▪
I will be a Villain, forget my vows of Love, made to Lucretia,
And Sacrifice both her, and those to interest.
Oh how I hate this whining and dissembling!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Do, Triumph o're a wretched man, Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: How! Wretched in loving me so intirely, or that you cannot marry my Mother, and be master of her mighty Fortune? 'Tis a temptation indeed, so between Love and Interest, hang me if ever I saw so simple a look as you put on when my Mother made Love to you.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: You may easily guess the confusion of a man in my circumstances, to be languishing for the lov'd Daughter, and pursu'd by the hated Mother, whom if I refuse will ruin all my hopes of thee.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Refuse her! I hope you have more wit?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.p: Lucretia, cou'd she make a Monarch of me, I cou'd not marry her.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: And you wou'd be so wise to tell her so?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I would no more abuse her, than I cou'd love her.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Yet that last must be done.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Dost believe me so wicked to think I mean in earnest? No, tell her me a fine story of Love, and liking, gaze on her, kiss her hands, and sigh, commend her face and shape, swear she's the miracle of the Age for wit, cry up her Learning, vow you were an Ass, not to be sensible of her perfections all this while, what a Coxcombe, to doat upon the Daughter when such charms were so visible in the Mother? Faith she'l believe all this.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: It may be so, but what will all this serve for?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: To give us time and opportunity to deceive her, or I'me mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I cannot teach my Tongue so much deceit.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
You may be a fool and cry, Indeed forsooth I cannot love, for alas I have lost my heart, and am unworthy of your proffer'd blessings, — doe, and see her marry me in spight to this
Fop Easy, this Knight of Nonsence; no, no, dissemble me handsomely and like a Gentleman, and then expect your good fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, your Mother's coming.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Away then, she must not see us together, she thinks you gon.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: But must I carry off no comfort with me?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Will you expose me to the incens'd jealousy of a Parent? goe or I shall hate ye,— Thrusts him out.

div.head: SCENE A Garden.
div.stage: Enter Maundy by dark: opens the Garden door.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p:
Now am I return'd to my old trade again, fetch and carry my Ladies Lovers, I was afraid when she had been married these night-works wou'd have ended, but to say truth, there's a Conscience to be used in all things, and there's no reason she shou'd languish with an old man when a young man may be had. — The door opens, he's come, —
Enter Lodwick. I see you're a punctual Lover Sir, Pray follow me as softly as you can.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This is some one whom I perceive Isabella has made the Confident to our Amours. — Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene draws off, and discovers La. Fancy in her Night-gown, in a Chamber as by the dark.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh the agreeable confusion of a Lover high with expectation of the approaching bliss! What tremblings between joy and fear possess me? All my whole Soul is taken up with Wittmore, I've no Idea's, no thoughts but of Wittmore, and sure my tongue can speak no other language, but his name.— Who's there?

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p:
Madam, 'tis I, and your expected Lover here — I put him into your hands, and will wait your commands in the next Chamber.
Ex. Maund.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Where are you my dearest Creature?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Here, — give me your hand, I'le lead you to those joys we both so long have sight for.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hah! to joys? sure she doth but dally with me,— Aside.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Why come you not on my Dear?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And yet, why this admission? and i'th' dark too, if she design'd me none but vertuous Favours? — What damn'd temptation's this?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Are you bewitch'd, what is't that frights you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I me fixt, Death, was ever such a Lover?
Just ready for the highest joys of Love,
And like a bashfull Girl restrain'd by fear
Of an insuing Infamy, — I hate to Cuckold my own Expectations.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Heavens! what can you mean?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Death, what's this,— sure 'tis not Vertue in me, —Pray Heaven it be not impotence! — Where got I this damn'd honesty which I never found my self master of till now? —why shou'd it seize me when I had least need on't?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: What ails you? are you mad? —we are safe, and free as Winds let loose to ruffle all the Groves, what is't delays you then? Soft.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pox o' this thought of Wife, the very name destroys my appetite,
Oh with what vigor I could deal my Love
To some fair lewd, unknown,
To whom I'de never made a serious vow?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Tell me the Mystery of this sudden coldness? have I kept my Husband in Town for this? Nay, perswaded him to be very sick to serve our purpose, and am I thus rewarded! — ungrateful man!

sp.speaker: Lod.
