sp.p: Hah, — 'tis not Isabella's voice, —your Husband say you? — Takes hold greedily of her hand.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.l: Is safe, from any fear of interrupting us.
Come — these delays do ill consist with Love
And our desires; at least if they are equal.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Death 'tis the charming Mother!
What lucky Star directed me to night!
O my fair dear dissembler, let us haste
To pay the mighty Tribute due to Love.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.l: Follow me then with careful silence, — for Isabella's Chamber joyns to this, and she may hear us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Not Flowers grow, nor smooth streams glide away,
Not absent Lovers sigh, nor breaks the day
More silently than I'le those joys receive,
Which Love and Darkness do conspire to give. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene changes again to a Garden. Enter Isabella and Fanny in their Night-gowns.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well I have no mind to let this dear mad Devil Lodwick in to night.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Why Sister, this is not the first venture you have made of this kind, at this hour, and in this place, these Arbours were they tell-tales, cou'd discover many pretty stories of your loves, and do you think they'l be less faithful now? Pray trust 'em once again. Oh I do so love to hear Mr. Lodwick protest, and vow, and swear, and dissemble, and when you don't believe him, rail at you,— a vads 'tis the prettiest man —

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I have a strange apprehension of being surpris'd to night.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I'le warant you, I'le sit on yon Bank of Pinks, and when I hear a noise I'le come and tell you, so Lodwick may slip out at the back gate, and we may be walking up and down as if we meant no harm.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You'l grow very expert in the arts of Love Fanny?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: When I am big enough I shall do my endeavour, for I have heard you say, Women were born to no other end than to love: And 'tis fit I should learn to live and die in my calling, — Come open the Gate or you'l repent it, we shall have my Father marry you within a day or two to that ugly man that speaks hard words. —a yads I can't abide him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p:
Why 'tis Mr. Lodwick at the Garden door,— let him
in whilst I'le to my Flowery Bank and stand Centinel.—

div.stage: Runs off. Isabella opens the Gate.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Speak low, who should it be but the kind fool her self who can deny you nothing, but what you dare not take?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Not take! what's that? hast thou reserves in store?
—Oh come and let me lead thee to thy Bed,
Or seat thee on some Bank of softer Flowers,
Where I may rifle all thy unknown store.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How! surely you're not in earnest? —Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Love thee! by thy dear self all that my Soul adores,
I'me all impatient Flame! all over Love!
—You do not use to doubt, but since you doe,
Come, and I'le satisfy thy obliging fears,
And give thee proofs how much my Soul is thine,
I'le breath it all a-new into thy bosom, —
Oh thou art fit for the transporting Play,
All loose and wanton, like the Queen of Love
When she descends to meet the Youth in shades.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And are you Sir in earnest? can it be?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: That question was severe, what means my Love!
What pretty art is this to blow my flame,
Are you not mine? did we not meet t'injoy?
I came not with more vigorous eager hast,
When our first Sacrifice to Love we paid,
Than to perform that Ceremony now.
Come do not let the Sacred Fire burn out
Which only was prepar'd for Love's rich Altar,
And this is the Divine, dark, silent Minute.— Goes to lead her off.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Hold Ravisher, and know this sawcy Passion
Has render'd back your interest. Now I hate ye,
And my Obedience to my Father's will
Shall marry me to Fain-love, and I'le despise ye. Flings from him.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hah! Isabella! Death I have made sweet work,—stay gentle maid, — she'l ruin all if she goe — stay — she knew me, and cunningly drew me to this discovery; I'le after her and undeceive her. Runs after her.

div.stage: A confus'd Noise of the Serenade, the Scene draws off to La. Fancy's Antichamber.
Enter Isabella groping as in the dark.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Pray Heaven I get undiscover'd to my Chamber, where I'le make Vows against this perjur'd Man; hah, sure he follows still; no Wood Nymph ever fled before a Satyr, with half that trembling haste I flew from Lodwick, —oh he has lost his Vertue and undone me. Goes out groping, and the noise of Serenade again.

div.stage: Scene changes to Lady Fancy's Bed-chamber, discovers her as before; Lodwick as just risen in disorder from the Bed: buttoning himself and setting himself in order; and noise at the door of unlatching it.
Enter Isabella groping, Sir Patient without.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: It is this Door that open'd, and which I thought I had secur'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh insupportable, abominable, and not to be indur'd!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Hah my Father! I'me discover'd and pursu'd, —grant me to find the Bed.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Heav'ns 'twas my Husbands Voice, sure we're betray'd. It must be so, for what Devil but that of Jealousy, cou'd raise him at this late hour?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Hah, where am I, and who is't that speaks. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So, he must know that I have made a Cuckold of him.

sp.speaker: S. P.
sp.p: Within, call up my men, the Coachman, Groom, and Butler; the Footmen, Cook and Gardener, bid 'em all rise and Arm, with long Staff, Spade and Pitchfork, and sally out upon the wicked.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Short! what a death shall I dye,—is there no place of safety hereabouts—for there is no resisting these unmercifull Weapons.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A mans Voice!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I know of none, nor how to prevent your discovery.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh oh lead me forward, I'le lye here on the Garden side, out of the hearing of this Hellish Noise.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Hah Noise —what means he?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay I know not, is there no escaping? —

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Who can they be that talk thus? sure I have mistook my chamber.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh he's coming in—I'me ruin'd, what shall we doe? here—get into the Bed—and cover your self with the clothes— quickly —oh my Confusion will betray me.

div.stage: Lodwick gets into the Bed, Isabella hides behind the Curtain very near to him.
Enter Sir Patient led by Nurse and Maundy with Lights.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Pray go back Sir, my poor Lady will be frighted out of her wits at this danger you put your self into, the noise shall be still'd.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh what's the matter with my Love, what, do you mean to murder him? oh lead him instantly back to his Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh oh, no, I'le lye here —put me to Bed, oh I faint, —my Chamber's possest with twenty thousand evil Spirits.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Possest! what sickly Fancy's this?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah the house is beset, surrounded and confounded with profane tinkling, with Popish Horn-Pipes and Jesuitical Cymballs, more Antichristian and Abominable then Organs, or Anthems.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Yea verily, and surely it is the spawn of Cathedrall Instruments plaid on by Babylonish Minstrells, only to disturb the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Aye 'tis so, call up my Servants, and let them be first chastis'd and then hang'd, accuse 'em for French Papishes, that had a design to fire the City, or any thing—oh I shall dye— lead me gently to this Bed.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: To hinder him will discover all — stay Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah my Lady turn'd rebellious! Throws himself forward to the Bed. —put me to Bed I say, hah—what's here— what art thou —a Man— hah, a Man, Treason! betray'd! my Bed's defil'd, my Lady Polluted, and I am Cornuted, oh thou Vile Serpent of my Bosome! She stands with her Face towards the Stage in signes of fear.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Man, and in my Vertuous Lady Mothers Chamber! how fortunate was I to light on this discovery!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Well, Sir, — since you have seen him, I beseech you for my sake, Dear, Pardon him this one time. Cokesing him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Thou beg his Pardon? oh was ever heard such Impudence!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Indeed my Love, he is to blame, but we that are judicious should bear with the frailties of Youth.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh insupportable Audacity! —what canst thou say false Woman?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Truly not much in his defence my dear.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh cunning Devil. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: But Sir, to hide the weakness of your Daughter, I have a little strain'd my Modesty.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Heav'ns! what says she?—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: 'Tis Isabella's Lover Sir, whom I've conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A good hint to save both our Credits.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How Mr. Fain-love mean you?

div.stage: Lodwick rises and comes a little more forward, Isabella does the like till both meet at the feet of the Bed and start, Lodwick looking simply.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Aye my dear, Mr. Fain-love.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Isabella here! must she know too what a fine inconstant Dog I am? —

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Lodwick! and in my Mothers Chamber! may I believe my Eyes?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But how got he hither — tell me that! oh Youth, Youth, to what degree of wickedness art thou arriv'd?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: She appointed him to come this night Sir, and he going to her Chamber, by mistake came into mine, it being the next to her's.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: But Lord Sir, had you heard how my Lady school'd him, whilst I ran down to fetch a light!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Now does my Conscience tell me, I am a damn'd Villain.—
Aside, looking pitifully on Isabella.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: But the poor Man presently perceiv'd his mistake, and beg'd my Pardon in such feeling termes —that I vow I had not the heart to deny it him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh Traytor! wou'd thou hadst been that Ravisher I took thee for, rather then such a Villain — false! and with my Mother too!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: And just then Sir you came to the door, and lest you shou'd see him, intreated me to hide him from your Anger, —the offence is not so hainous Sir, considering he's so soon to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: —Well Sir, and what have you to say in your defence? —hah—how Mr. Knowell!— worse and worse —why how came you hither Sir? hah,—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Not Wittmore! oh I am ruin'd and betray'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, Isabella here too!—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes Sir, to justify her Innocence.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah! Innocence! and justify! take her away, go out of my sight thou limb of Satan, — take her away I say, I'le talk with you to morrow, Lady fine tricks— I will.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: — And I'le know before I sleep the mystery of all this, and who 'twas this faithless Man sent in his room to deceive me in the Garden.— Goes out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A plague of all ill-luck—how the Devil came she hither? I must follow and reconcile her.—
Going out, Sir Patient stays him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Nay Sir, we must not part so till I have known the truth of this business I take it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Truth Sir, oh all that your fair Lady has said, Sir, I must confess, her Eyes have wounded me enough with Anger, you need not add more to my shame. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Some little comfort yet that he prov'd indeed to be Isabella's Lover: oh that I should mistake so unluckily! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why, I thought it had been Mr. Fain-love.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: By all that's good, and so did I.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I know you did Madam or you had not been so kind to me: your servant dear Madam, —
Going, Sir Patient stays him.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Pray Sir let him goe, oh how I abominate the sight of a man that cou'd be so wicked as he has been!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ha, —good Lady, excellent woman, well Sir for my Ladies sake I'le let you pass with this, but if I catch you here again, I shall spoil your intrigues, Sir, marry shall I, and so rest ye satisfy'd Sir.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: At this time, I am Sir —Madam a thousand blessings on you for this goodness. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Ten thousand Curses upon thee, —go boast the ruine you have made.
Aside to Lod.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Come, no more anger now my Lady; the Gentleman's sorry you see, I'le marry my pert Huswife to morrow for this, —Maundy see the Gentleman safe out, — ah — put me to Bed, ah—this nights work will kill me, ah, ah —

div.stage: Ex. Lodwick and Maundy. The Scene draws over Sir Patient and Lady: draws again and discovers the Garden, Wittmore, Fanny and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: How, Mr. Fain-love? it cannot be.—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Indeed Sister 'tis the same for all he talks so, and he told me his coming was but to try your vertue only.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick and Maundy as passing over, but stand.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: That Fain-love whom I am so soon to marry! and but this day courted me in another Dialect!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: That was my Policy Madam, to pass upon your Father with. But I'me a Man that knows the value of the Fair, and saw charms of Beauty and of wit in you, that taught me to know the way to your heart was to appear my self, which now I doe. Why did you leave me so unkindly but now?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hah, what's this? whilst I was grafting horns on another's head, some kind friend was doing that good office for me.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Sure 'tis Wittmore! —oh that dissembler—this was his Plot upon my Lady, to gain time with Isabella. Aside.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And being so near my happiness, can you blame me, if I made a tryall whether your Virtue were agreable to your Beauty, great, and to be equally ador'd?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Death, I've heard enough to forfeit all my patience— Draw Sir and make a tryall of your Courage too.—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hah! what desperate fool art thou? draws.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: One that will see thee fairly damn'd e're yield his Interest up in Isabella —oh thou false Woman!

div.stage: They fight out, Isabella and Maundy run off.
Scene changes to the long Street, a Pageant of an Elephant coming from the farther end with Sir Credulous on it, and several others playing on strange confused Instruments.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
This sure is extraordinary, or the Devil's in't, and I'le ne're trust Serenade more. Come forward and all play again. —hold, hold, now for the Song, which because I wou'd have most Deliciously and Melodiously sung, I'le sing my self: look ye,— hum — hum.—
Sir Credulous should have Sung.
THou grief of my heart, and thou Pearl of my Eyes,
D'on on Flannel Peticoat quickly, and rise:
And from thy resplendent window discover
A face that wou'd mortify any young Lover:
For I like great Jove Transformed do wooe,
And am Amorous Owl, To wit to woo, to wit to woo.
A Lover Ads Zoz is a sort of a tool
That of all things you best may compare to an Owl:
For in some dark shades he delights still to sit,
And all the night long he cries Wo to wit.
Then rise my bright Cloris and d'on on ship-shoe:
And hear thy Amorous Owl chant, Wit to woo, wit to woo.
—Well, this won't do, for I perceive no Window open, nor Lady-bright appear, to talk obligingly, — perhaps the Song does not please her, you Ballad-singers, have you no good Songs of another fashion?

sp.speaker: 1. Man.
sp.p: Yes Sir, several, Robin, — Hark how the Waters fall, fall, fall,—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How Man! Zoz, remove us farther off, sor fear of wetting.

sp.speaker: 1. Man.
sp.p: No no, Sir, I only gave my fellow a hint of an excellent Ballad that begins — Ill wodded joys how quickly do you fade. Sings.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Aye, aye that, we'l have that,—Ill wodded joys how quickly do you fade, — [Sings] That's excellent! Oh now the
Windows open, now, now show your capering tricks. Valting.

div.stage: Enter a company of fellows as out of Sir Patient's House, led on by a precise Clerk, all armed with odd weapons.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Verily, verily, here be these Babes of Perdition, these Children of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: A pox of your Babes and Children, they are men and Sons of Whores whom we must bang confoundedly, for not letting honest godly People rest quietly in their Beds at Midnight.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: There with a Pox to you, cannot a Right-worshipful Knight that has been sick these Twenty Years with taking Physick, sleep quietly in his own House for you, and must we be rais'd out of our Beds to quiet your Hell-pipes in the Devil's name?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Down with Gog and Magog, there, there's the rotten Bell-wether that leads the rest astray, and defiles the whole flock.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Hang your Preaching and let's come to him, we'l maule him.
Beat Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh Quarter Quarter, Murther, help, Murther, Murther.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Damn these Rascalls who e're they were, that so unluckily redeem'd a Rival from my fury, — Hah, they are here,— Egad I'le have one touch more with 'em, — the dogs are spoiling my design'd Serenade too — have amongst ye, — Sir Credulous how is't? Fights and beats 'em off.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Who's there, Lodwick! Oh dear Lad, is't thou that hast redeem'd me from the inchanted Cudgels that demolish'd my triumphant Pageant, and confounded my Serenade? Zoz, I'me half kill'd man, — I have never a whole Bone about me sure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come in with me — a plague upon the Rascal that. escap't me. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV
SCENE I. Lady Knowel's House.
div.stage: Enter Lucretia followed by Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: MArry'd to morrow! and leave my Mother the possession of Leander? I'le die a thousand Deaths first,— How the Fool haunts me! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay delicious Lady, you may say your Pleasure, but I will justify the Serenade to be as high a piece of Gallantry as was ever practised in our Age, tho' not comparable to your Charms and Celestial Graces, which shou'd I praise as I ought, 'twou'd require more time than the Sun employs in his Natural motion between the Tropicks; that is to say a whole Year, (for by the way, I am no Copernican) for, Dear Madam, you must know my Rhetorick Master, — I say my Rhetorick Master who was —

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: As great a Coxcombe as your self, — pray leave me I am serious, — I must go seek out Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Leave ye! I thank you for that I'faith, before I have spoke out my speech, therefore I say Divine Lady — because my Rhetorick Master commanded the frequent use of Hypallages, Allegories, and the richest Figures of that beauteous Art, — because my Rhetorick,—

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I must leave the Fool, follow if you dare, for I have no leasure to attend your nonsense. Goes out.

sp.speaker: La. Kno.
sp.p: What, alone Sir Credulous? I left you with Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Lucretia! I'me sure she makes a very Tarquinius Sextus of me, and all about this Serenade,— I protest and vow, incomparable Lady, I had begun the sweetest Speech to her — tho' I say't, such Flowers of Rhetorick — 'twou'd have been the very Nosegay of Eloquence, so it wou'd; and like an ungratefull illiterate Woman as she is, she left me in the very middle on't, so snuffy I'le warrant.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Be not discourag'd Sir, I'le adapt her to a reconciliation, Lovers must sometimes expect these little Belli-fugaces, the Grecians therefore truly named Love Glucupicros Eros.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay bright Lady, I am as little discourag'd as another, but I'me sorry I gave so extraordinary a Serenade to so little purpose.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Name it no more, 'twas onely a Gallantry mistaken, but I'le accelerate your felicity, and to morrow shall conclude the great dispute, since there is such Volubility and Vicissitude in Mundan affairs.— Goes out.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, stays Sir Credulous as he is going out the other way.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir Credulous, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Zoz, what a Question's there, dost not know I am to untie the Virgin Zone to morrow, that is, barter Maiden-heads with thy Sister, that is, to be Married to her man, and I must to Lincolns-Inne to my Counsel about it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My Sister just now told me of it, but Sir, you must not stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have you made your Will?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: My Will! no, why my Will man?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Then for the good of your Friends and Posterity stir not from this place.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Good Lord, Lodwick, thou art the strangest Man, — what do ye mean to fright a body thus?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You remember the Serenade last night?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Remember it! Zoz I think I do, here be the marks on't sure. — Pulls off his Peruke and shews his head broke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ads me, your head's broke.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: My head broke! why 'twas a hundred to one but my neck had been broke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Faith not unlikely, — you know the next House is Sir Patient Fancy's; Isabella too you know is his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Yes, yes she was by, when I made my dumb Oration.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The same, — this Lady has a Lover, a mad, furious, sighting killing Hector, (as you know there are enough about this Town) this Monsieur supposing you to be a Rival, and that your Serenade was addrest to her—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Enough, I understand you, set those Rogues on to murder me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twere no worse.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Worse! Zoz man, what the Devil can be worse?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why he has vow'd to kill you himself where-ever he meets you, and now waits below to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sha, sha, if that be all I'le to him immediately, and make Affidavit I never had any such design. Madam Isabella? ha, ha, alas poor man, I have some body else to think on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Affidavit! why he'l not believe you, should you sweat your heart out, some body has possest him that you are a damn'd Fool, and a most egregious Coward, a fellow that to save your life, will swear any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What cursed luck's this! — why how came he to know I liv'd here?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I believe he might have it from Leander who is his friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Leander, I must confess I never lik'd that Leander, since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He has deceiv'd us all that's the truth on't, for I have lately found out too, that he's your Rival, and has a kind of a —

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Smattering to my Mistress, hah, and therefore wou'd not be wanting to give me a lift out of this world, but I shall give him such a go-by — my Lady Knowell understands the difference between Three thousand a year and — prethee what's his Estate?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Shaw — not sufficient to pay Surgeons Bills.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Alas poor Ratt, how does he live then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hang him, the Ladies keep him, 'tis a good handsom fellow and has a pretty Town Wit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: He a Wit! what, I'le warrant he writes Lampoons, rails at Plays, curses all Poetry but his own, and mimicks the Players— ha,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Some such common Notions he has that deceive the Ignorant Rabble, amongst whom he passes for a very smart Fellow, —'s life he's here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why—what shall I doe, he will not affront me before company? hah!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not in our house Sir, —bear up and take no notice on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No notice, quoth he? why my very fears will betray me.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Let me alone,—Lodwick, I met just now with an Italian Merchant, who has made me such a Present!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What is't prethee?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: A sort of specifick Poyson for all the Senses, especially for that of smelling, so that had I a Rival, and I shou'd see him at any reasonable distance, I cou'd direct a little of this Scent up to his Brain so subtlely, that it shall not fail of Execution in a day or two.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How—Poyson! Shewing great signes of fear, and holding his Nose.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Nay should I see him in the midst of a thousand People, I can so direct it that it shall assault my Enemies Nostrils only, without any effects on the rest of the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh—I'me a dead man!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Perhaps some little sneezing or so, no harm; but my Enemy's a dead man Sir, kill'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why, this is the most damnable Italian trick I ever heard of; why this outdoes the famous Poysoner Madam Brenvilliers, well, here's no jesting I perceive that, Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Fear nothing, I'le secure you. Aside to him.
Enter Wittmore. —Wittmore! how is't friend! thou lookest cloudy.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: You'le hardly blame me Gentlemen, when you shall know what a Damn'd unfortunate Rascal I am.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prethee what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: — Why I am to be Marry'd Gentlemen, Marry'd to Day.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How, Marry'd! nay Gad then thou'st reason, —but to whom prethee?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: There's the Devil on't again, to a fine young, fair, brisk Woman that has all the temptations Heaven can give her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What pity 'tis they shou'd be bestow'd to so wicked an end! Is this your intrigue that has been so long conceal'd from your Friends?

sp.speaker: Leand.
sp.p: We thought 't had been some kind Amour, something of Love and Honour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is she Rich? if she be wonderous Rich, we'le excuse thee.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Her Fortune will be sutable to the Joynture I shall make her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis like to prove a hopefull Match, — what a Pox can provoke thee to this, dost love her?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: No there's another Plague, I am cursedly in love elsewhere, and this was but a false address to hide that reall one.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How, love another? in what quality, and manner?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: As a man ought to Love, with a good substantiall Passion, without any design but that of right-down honest Injoyment.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aye, now we understand thee, this is something! ah friend! I had such an adventure last night! — you may talk of you intrigues and substantiall Pleasures, but if any of you can match mine, — Egad I'le forswear womankind.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: An adventure! prethee where?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What, last night, when you rescu'd me from the Billbo-blades? indeed ye lookt a little furiously.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I had reason, I was just then come out of a Garden from fighting with a man whom I found with my Mistress, and I had at least known who't had been but for the coming of those Rascalls that set on you, who parted us, whilst he made his escape in the crowd.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Death! that was I, who for fear of being known got away, was't he then that I fought with, and whom I learnt lov'd Isabella! Aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You must know Gentlemen, I have a sort of a Matrimoniall kindness for a very pretty woman, she whom I tell you I disturb'd in the Garden, and last night she made me an assignation in her Chamber: when I came to the garden Door by which I was to have admittance, I found a kind of Necessary call'd a Bawdy waiting-woman, whom I follow'd, and thought she wou'd have conducted me to the right woman; but I was luckily and in the dark led into a Ladies Chamber, who took me for a Lover she expected, — I found my happy mistake, and wou'd not undeceive her.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: This cou'd be none but Lucia. Aside. — Well Sir, and what did you do there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Doe? why what dost think? all that a man inspir'd by Love cou'd doe, I followed all the Dictates of Nature, Youth and Vigor!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Oh hold my heart—or I shall kill the Traytor. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Follow'd all the Dictates of Nature, Youth, and Vigour? prethee what's that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I kist a thousand times her balmy Lips, and greedily took in the nimble Sighs she breath'd into my Soul!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Oh I can scarce contain my self. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Pshaw, is that all man?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I claspt her lovely Body in my Armes, and laid my Bosom to her panting Breast.
Trembling she seem'd all love and soft desire,
And I all burning in a youthfull fire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Bless us, the Man's in a Rapture.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Damnation on them both.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well to the point man, what didst doe all this while▪

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Faith I fancy he did not sleep, Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No friend, she had too many Charms to keep me waking.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Had she so? I shou'd have beg'd her Charms pardon, I tell her that though.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Curse on my sloath, oh how shall I dissemble? Aside.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Thy adventure was pretty lucky —but Wittmore thou lost not relish it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: My Mind's upon my Marriage Sir, — if I thought he lov'd Isabella I wou'd marry her to be reveng'd on him, at least Ile vex his Soul as he has tortur'd mine, —well Gentlemen, you'le dine with me, —and give me your opinion of my Wife.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Where dost thou keep the Ceremony?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: At Sir Patient Fancyes, my Father in Law.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How! Sir Patient Fancy to be your Father in Law?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: My Uncle!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: He's fir'd—'tis his Daughter Sir I am to Marry.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Isabella! Leander, can it be? —can she consent to this? and can she love you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why Sir, what do you see in me, shou'd render me unfit to be belov'd? angry.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry'd to day! by Heaven it must not be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why Sir, I hope this is not the kind Lady who was so soft, so sweet, and charming last night.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold Sir—we yet are friends.—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And might have still been so, hadst thou not basely rob'd me of my Interest.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Death! do you speak my Language? Ready to draw.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: No, take a secret from my angry heart, which all its friendship to thee cou'd not make me utter, —it was my Mistress you surpris'd last night.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hah, my Lady Fancy his Mistress? Curse on my prating Tongue.— Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What a Devil's all this, hard words, heart-burnings, resentments and all that?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: You are not quarrelling I hope, my friends?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: All this Sir we suspected, and smok't your borrowing Mony last night, and what I said was to gain the mighty secret that had been so long kept from your friends—but thou hast done a baseness.— layes his hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Hold, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Did you not rob me of the Victory then I've been so long a toyling for?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I had 'twou'd not have made her guilty, nor me a Criminall, she taking me for one she lov'd, and I her for one that had no interest in my friend, and who the Devil wou'd have refus'd so fine a woman? nor had I, but that I was prevented by her Husband, —but Isabella Sir you must resign.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I will, provided that our friendship's safe; I am this day to marry her, and if you can find a means to do't in my room, I shall resign my interest to my friend, for 'tis the lovely Mother I adore!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And was it you I fought with in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
Yes, and thereby hangs a tale of a mistake almost equall to thine, which I'le at leasure tell you.
Talks to Lod. and Lean.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I'me glad they're friends, Zoz here was like to have been a pretty business, what Damnable work this same womankind makes in a Nation of Fools that are Lovers!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
Look ye, I'me a Damn'd dull fellow at invention, I'le therefore leave you to contrive matters by your selves, whilst I'le go try how kind fortune will be to me this Morning, and see in what readiness my Bride is; what you do must be thought on
suddainly, I'le wait on you anon, and let you know how matters goe, —I'me as impatient to know the truth of this, as for an opportunity to injoy Lucia. goes out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Leander what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: You were best — consult your Mother and Sister, women are best at intrigues of this kind: but what becomes of me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Let me alone to dispatch this fool, I long to have him out of the way, he begins to grow troublesome—but now my Mother expects you.—

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p:
Prethee be carefull of me.—
Ex. Leander.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What was this long whisper, something about me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why yes faith I was perswading him to speak to his friend about this business, but he swears there's no hopes of a reconciliation, you are a dead man unless some cleanly conveyance of you be soon thought on.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why, I'le keep within doors and defy malice and foul weather.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O he means to get a warrant and search for stolen goods, prohibited Commodities or Conventicles, there's a thousand civill pretences in this Town to commit outrages —let me see.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well I have thought, —and of such a business, that the Devil's in't if you don't say I am a man of intrigue.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, I must have leave to laugh to think how neatly I shall defeat this son of a whore of a thunder thumping Hector.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Be serious Sir, this is no laughing matter, if I might advise, you should steal into the Country, for two or three days till the business be blown over.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Lord, thou art so hasty and conceited of thy own invention, thou wilt not give a man leave to think in thy company, why these were my very thoughts, nay more, I have found a way to get off clever, though he watch me as narrowly as an inrag'd Serjeant upon an escape.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That indeed wou'd be a Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Why, look ye, do ye see that great Basket there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I doe, — this you mean.— pulls in a Basket.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Very well, put me into this Basket, and cord me down, send for a couple of Porters, hoist me away with a Direction,
to an old Uncle of mine, one Sir Anthony Bubleton at Bubleton-Hall in Essex, and then Whip slap dash, as Nokes says in the Play, I'me gone and who's the wiser.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I like it well.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay lose no time in applauding, I'le in, the Carrier goes this morning, farewell Lodwick.— Goes into the Basket. I'le be here again on Thursday. Lod. writes a direction.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: By all means Sir, — Who's there, — call a couple of Porters. Ex. Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: One word more, the Carrier lies at the Bell in Friday-street, pray take care they set me not on my head.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come hither, cord up this Basket, and carry it where he shall direct — Leander will never think he's free from a Rival till he have him in his possession, — To Mr. Leander Fancy's at the next door; say 'tis things for him out of the Countrey.— Write a direction to him on the Basket lid. Aside to the Boy.

div.stage: Porters going to carry off the Basket on a long Pole between 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: What's this? whither goes this Basket?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ah Lord! they are come with the Warrant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Only Books Madam offer'd me to buy, but they do not please me.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Books? nay then set down the Basket Fellows, and let me peruse 'em, who were the Authors, and what their Language?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Pox of all Learning I say, — 'tis my Mother-in-Law. Porters going to set down the Basket.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold, hold Madam, they are only English, and some Law-French.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh faugh, how I hate that vile sort of reading! up with 'em again fellows, and away. The Porters take up and go out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: God-a-mercy Law-French. Aside.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Law-French! out upon't, I cou'd find in my heart to have the Porters bring it back, and have it burnt for a Heresy to Learning.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Or thrown into the Thames, that it may float back to Normandy to have the Language new modell'd.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: You say well, but what's all this ad Iphicli bonis, where's Sir Credulous all this while? his affairs expect him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So does Leander your Ladiship within.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Leander! Hymen, Hymenaee, I'le wait on him, Lodwick I am resolv'd you shall marry Isabella too, I have a design in my head that cannot fail to give you the possession of her within this two or three hours.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Such an Indulgence will make me the happiest of men, and I have something to say to your Ladiship that will oblige you to hasten the design.—

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Come in and let me know it. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. A Table and Chairs.
div.stage: Enter Lady Fancy in a Morning dress, Maundy with Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Wittmore in the Garden saist thou with Isabella! Oh Perjur'd man! it was by his contrivance then I was betray'd last night.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: I thought so too at first Madam, till going to conduct Mr. Knowel through the Garden, he finding Mr. Wittmore there with Isabella, drew on him, and they both fought out of the Garden, what mischief's done▪ I know not, — but Madam, I hope Mr. Knowel was not uncivil to your Ladiship: I had no time to ask what past between you.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh name it not! I gave him all I had reserved for Wittmore! I was so possest with the thoughts of that dear false one, I had no sense free to perceive the cheat,— but I will be reveng'd, — come let me end my Letter, we are safe from interruption.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Yes Madam, Sir Patient is not yet up, the Doctors have been with him, and tell him he is not so bad as we perswaded him.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: — And was he soft and kind? — By all that's good she loves him, and they contriv'd this meeting, — my Pen and Ink — I am impatient to unload my Soul of this great weight of jealousie.— Sits down and writes.

div.stage: Enter Sir Patient looking over her Shoulder a tip-toe.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Heaven! here's Sir Patient Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Hah, — and ▪tis too late to hide the Paper, — I was just going to subscribe my name.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pat.
sp.p: Good morrow, my Lady Fancy, your Ladiship is well imploy'd I see.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Indeed I was, and pleasantly too, I am writing a Love-letter Sir, — but my Dear, what makes you so soon up?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A Love-letter! — let me see't. Goes to take it.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I'le read it to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: What mean you Madam? Aside.

body.p: It was but yesterday you swore you lov'd me, and I poor easy fool believed, but your last nights Infidelity has undeceived my heart, and rendred you the falsest Man that ever Woman sight for. Tell me, how durst you, when I had prepared all things for our enjoyment, be so great a Devil to deceive my languishing expectations? And in your room send one that has undone —

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Sure she's mad to read this to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hum, — I profess ingenuously— I think it is indeed a Love-letter, — my Lady Fancy what means all this? as I take it here are Riddles and Mysteries in this business.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Which thus Sir I'le unfold.—
Takes this Pen and writes Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How! undone — your— Isabella, meaning my Daughter?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Yes my Dear, going this morning into her Chamber, she not being there, I took up a Letter that lay open on her
Table, and out of curiosity read it, as near as I can remember 'twas to this purpose, I writ it out now because I had a mind thou shou'd'st see't; for I can hide nothing from thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A very good Lady I profess, to whom is it directed?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Why, — Sir, — What shall I say, I cannot lay it now on Lodwick.— Aside. I believe she meant it to Mr. Fain-love, for whom else cou'd it be designd? she being so soon to marry him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, — Mr. Fain-love! so soon so fond and amorous!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Alas, 'tis the excusable fault of all young Women, thou knowest I was just such another fool to thee, so fond — and so in love.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ha, —thou wert indeed my Lady Fancy, indeed thou wert, — but I will keep the Letter however, that this idle Baggage may know I understand her tricks and intrigues. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Nay then 'twill out: no I beseech you Sir give me the Letter, I wou'd not for the World Isabella shou'd know of my theft, 'twou'd appear malicious in me, — besides Sir, it does not befit your Gravity to be concern'd in the little quarrels of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Lovers! Tell me not of Lovers, my Lady Fancy; with Reverence to your good Ladiship, I value not whether there be love between 'em or not, Pious Wedlock is my business, — nay, I will let him know his own too, that I will, with your Ladiship's permission.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: How unlucky I am!— Sir, as to his Chastisement, use your own discretion, in which you do abound most plentifully, — but pray let not Isabella hear of it, for as I wou'd preserve my duty to thee, by communicating all things to thee, so I wou'd conserve my good opinion with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah, what a blessing I possess in so excellent a Wife! and in regard I am every day descending to my Grave,— ah — I will no longer hide from thee the provision I have made for thee, in case I die. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: This is the Musick that I long'd to hear. —Die!—Oh that fatal word will kill me— [Weeps.] Name it no more if you'd preserve my life.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, — now cannot I refrain joyning with her in affectionate tears — no but do not weep for me my excellent Lady — for I have made a pretty competent Estate for thee, Eight thousand Pounds, which I have conceal'd in my Study behind the Wainscot on the left hand as you come in.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh tell not me of transitory wealth, for I'me resolv'd not to survive thee, Eight thousand Pounds say you? — Oh I cannot indure the thoughts on't. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Eight thousand Pounds just, my dearest Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh you'l make me desperate in naming it, — is it in Gold or Silver?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: In Gold my Dearest the most-part, the rest in Silver.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Good Heavens! why shou'd you take such pleasure in afflicting me. [Weeps.] — Behind the Wainscot say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Behind the Wainscot, prethee be pacifi'd, — thou makest me lose my greatest vertue, Moderation, to see thee thus, alas we're all born to die. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Again of dying! uncharitable man, why do you delight in tormenting me? — on the left hand say you as you go in?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: On the left hand my Love, had ever Man such a Wife?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh my Spirits fail me, —lead me, or I shall faint,— lead me to the Study and shew me where 'tis, — for I am able to hear no more of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I will, if you will promise indeed and indeed, not to grieve too much. Going to lead her out.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Heaven grant me some kind opportunity to speak with Lucia! hah, she's here, — and with her the fond Cuckold her Husband, — Death, he has spy'd me, there's no avoiding him. —

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh, are you there Sir? — Maundy look to my Lady, — I take it Sir, you have not dealt well with a person of my Authority and Gravity. Gropes for the Letter in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: So, this can be nothing less than my being found out to be no Yorkshire Esq: a Pox of my Geneva breeding, it must be so, what the Devil shall I say now?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: And this disingenuous dealing does ill become the person you have represented, I take it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Represented! Aye there 'tis, wou'd I were handsomely off o' this business; neither Lucia nor Maundy have any intelligence in their demure looks that can instruct a man, — why faith Sir, — I must confess, — I am to blame — and that I have — a —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh Maundy! he'l discover all, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Have what Sir?

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: From my violent passion for your Daughter. —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh I'me all confusion. —

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Egad I am i'th' wrong, I see by Lucia's looks.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: That you have Sir, you wou'd say, made a sport and May-game of the ingagement of your word; I take it Mr. Fain-love, 'tis not like the stock you came from.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Yes, I was like to have spoil'd all, 'sheart what fine work I had made —but most certainly he has discover'd my passion for his Wife, — well, Impudence assist me— I made Sir a trifle of my word Sir, from whom have you this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: From whom shou'd I Sir, but from my Daughter Isabella?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Isabella! The malicious Baggage understood to whom my first Courtship was address'd last night, and has betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: And Sir to let you see I utter nothing without precaution, pray read that Letter.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Hah — a Letter! what can this mean, — 'tis Lucia's hand, with Isabella's name to't, — Oh the dear cunning Creature to make her Husband the messenger too. [He Reads] — How, I send one in my room?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you think we do not know of the appointment you made last night, but having other affairs in hand than to keep your promise, you sent Mr. Knowel in your room, — false man.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: I send him Madam! I wou'd have sooner died.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sir as I take it he cou'd not have known of your designes and Rendezvous without your information, — were not you to have met my Daughter here to night Sir?

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, and I hope 'tis no such great crime, to desire a
little conversation with the fair person one loves, and is so soon to marry, which I was hinder'd from doing by the greatest and most unlucky misfortune that ever arriv'd: but for my sending him, Madam, credit me, there's nothing so much amazes me and afflicts me, as to know he was here.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: He speaks well, ingenuously he do's. — well Sir for your Father's sake, whose memory I reverence, I will for once forgive you, but let's have no more night-works, no more Gamballs I beseech you good Mr. Fain-love.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: I humbly thank ye Sir, and do beseech you to tell the dear Creature that writ this, that I love her more than life or fortune, and that I wou'd sooner have kill'd the man that usurp'd my place last night than have assisted him.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Were you not false then? — Now hang me if I do not credit him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Alas good Lady! how she's concern'd for my Interest, she's even jealous for my Daughter. Aside.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: False! charge me not with unprofitable sins; wou'd I refuse a Blessing, or blaspheme a Power that might undo me? wou'd I die in my full vigorous health, or live in constant pain? All this I cou'd, sooner than be untrue.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ingenuously, my Lady Fancy, he speaks discreetly, and to purpose.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Indeed my Dear he does, and like an honest Gentleman, and I shou'd think my self very unreasonable not to believe him, — and Sir I'le undertake your peace shall be made with your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Well, I am the most fortunate man in a Wife that ever had the blessing of a good one.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Madam, let me fall at your feet, and thank you for this Bounty. [Kneels.] — Make it your own case, and then consider what returns ought to be made to the most passionate and faithful of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I profess, a wonderful good natur'd youth this, rise Sir, my Lady Fancy shall do you all the kind Offices she can, o' my word she shall.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I'me all obedience Sir, and doubtless shall obey you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: You must, indeed you must, and Sir I'le defer your Happiness no longer, this day you shall be marry'd.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: This day Sir! — why, the Writings are not made.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: No matter Mr. Fainlove, her Portion shall be equivalent to the Jointure you shall make her, I take it, that's sufficient.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: A Jointure quoth he! it must be in New Eutopian Land then, — and must I depart thus, without a kind word, a look, or a billiet, to signify what I am to expect? Looking on her slils.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Come, my Lady Fancy, shall I wait on you down to Prayer? Sir you will go get your self in order for your Marriage, the great affair of human life, I must to my mornings Devotion: come Madam.
She endeavours to make signs to Wittmore.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Alas Sir, the sad discourse you lately made me, has so disorder'd me, and given me such a pain in my head, I am not able to endure the Psalm singing.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: This comes of your weeping, — but we'l omit that part of th'exercise, and have no Psalm sung.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh by no means Sir, 'twill scandalize the Brethren, for you know a Psalm is not sung so much out of devotion as 'tis to give notice of our Zeal and Pious intentions, 'tis a kind of Proclamation to the Neighbour-hood, and cannot be omitted, —Oh how my head aches!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: He were a damn'd dull Lover that cou'd not guess what she meant by this. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Well, my Lady Fancy, your Ladiship shall be obey'd, — come Sir, we'l leave her to her Women.
Ex. Sir Pat.

div.stage: As Wittmore goes out, he bows and looks on her, she gives him a sign.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: That kind look is a sufficient invitation.—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Maundy follow 'em down, and bring VVittmore back again,— [Exit Maund.] There's now a necessity of our contriving to avoid this marriage handsomely, —and we shall at least make two hours our own, I never wish'd well to long Prayers till this minute.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Oh my dear Lucia!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh VVittmore! I long to tell thee what a fatal mistake had like to have happen'd last night.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: My friend has told me all, and how he was prevented by the coming of your Husband from robbing me of those sacred delights I languish for, oh let us not lose inestimable time in dull talking, but haste to give each other the only confirmation we can give, how little we are our own.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I see Lodwick's a Man of Honour, and deserves a heart if I had one to give him. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. A Hall.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Roger, is Prayer ready, Roger?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Truely nay Sir, for Mr. Gogle hath taken too much of the Creature this Morning, and is not in case, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How mean you Sirrah, that Mr. Gogle is overtaken with Drink?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay Sir, he hath over-eaten himself at Breakfast only.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Alas and that's soon done, for he hath a sickly Stomach as well as I, poor man —where is Bartholomew, the Clerk, he must hold forth then to day.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Verily he is also disabled, for going forth last night by your commandment to smite the wicked, he received a blow over the Pericranium.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why how now Sirrah, Latin! the Language of the Beast! hah—and what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Which blow I doubt Sir, hath spoiled both his Praying and his Eating.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah! what a Family's here? no prayer to day!

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Nay verily it shall all out, I will be no more the dark lanthorn to the deeds of darkness.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Sir, this young Sinner has long been privy to all the daily and nightly meetings between Mr. Lodwick and Isabella, and just now I took her tying a letter to a string in the Garden which he drew up to his Window, and I have born it till my Conscience will bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Hah, so young a Bawd! —tell me Minion, —private
meeting! tell me truth I charge ye, when? where? how? and how often? oh she's debauch't! —her reputation's ruin'd, and she'le need a double Portion. Come tell me truth, for this little Finger here has told me all.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Oh Geminy Sir, then that little Finger's the hougesest great Lyer as ever was.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Huzy huzy —I will have thee whipt most unmercifully: Nurse fetch me the Rod.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Oh pardon me Sir this one time and I'le tell all. Kneels. —Sir— I have seen him in the Garden, but not very often.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Often! oh, my Family's dishonoured, tell me truly what he us'd to do there—or I will have thee whipt without cessation, oh I'me in a cold Sweat, there's my fine Maid, was he with her long?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Long enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Long enough! —oh 'tis so, long enough—for what, hah? my dainty Miss, tell me, and didst thou leave 'em?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: They us'd to send me to gather flowers to make Nosegays Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah, demonstration, 'tis evident if they were left alone that they were naught, I know't, —and where were they the while? in the close Arbour? —Aye Aye — I will have it cut down, it is the Pent-house of Iniquity, the very Coverlid of Sin.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: No Sir, they sat on the Primrose Bank.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What, did they sit all the while, or stand—or —lye —or— oh how was't?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: They only sat indeed Sir Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: And thou didst not hear a word they said all the while?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Yes I did Sir, and the man talkt a great deal of this, and of that, and of t'other, and all the while threw Jesimine in her bosome.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Well said, and did he nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir Father, nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But what did she say to the man again?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: She said, let me see, —Aye she said, Lord you'le forget your self, and stay till somebody catch us.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah, very fine, —then what said he?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Then he said, Well if I must be gon, let me leave thee with this hearty curse, A Pox take thee all over for making me love thee so confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh horrible!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: —Oh I cou'd live here for ever, —that was when he kist her— her hand only, are you not a Damn'd woman for making so fond a Puppy of me?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh unheard of wickedness!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Wou'd the Devil had thee and all thy family, e're I had seen thy Cursed face.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh I'le hear no more, —I'le hear no more—why what a Blasphemous wretch is this!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Pray Sir Father, do not tell my Sister of this, she'le be horribly angry with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
No no, get you gon, —oh I am heart-sick — I'le up and consult with my Lady what's fit to be done in this affair, oh never was the like heard of.—
Goes out, Fanny goes the other way.

div.stage: Scene, the Lady Fancies Bedchamber, she's discovered with Wittmore in disorder. A Table, Sword, and Hatt.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: O Madam, Sir Patient's coming up.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: Coming up say you!

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: He's almost on the top of the Stairs, Madam.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh Damn him, I know not, if he see thee here after my pretended Illness, he must needs discover why I feign'd, —I have no Excuse ready, —this Chamber's unlucky, there's no avoiding him, here — step behind the Bed, perhaps he has only forgot his Psalm Book and will not stay long. Wittmore runs behind the Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh, oh, pardon this interruption my Lady Fancy —oh I am half kill'd, my Daughter, my Honour—my Daughter, my Reputation.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Good Heavens Sir, is she dead?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
I wou'd she were, her Portion and her Honour wou'd then be sav'd, but oh I'me sick at heart, Maundy, fetch me the
Bottle of Mirabilis in the Closet, — she's wanton — unchast,
Enter Maundy with the Bottle.
oh I cannot speak it, oh the Bottle— [Drinks] she has lost her Fame, —her Shame—her Name—oh [Drinks] this is not the right Bottle—that with the red Cork [Drinks]
Ex. Maundy. —and is grown a very t'other end of the town Creature, a very Apple of Sodom, fair without and filthy within, what shall we
Enter Maundy. doe with her? she's lost, undone; [Drinks] hah —let me see, [Drinks] this is— [Drinks] not as I take it— [Drinks] —no— 'tis not the right—she's naught, —she's lewd, — [Drinks] — oh how you Vex me— [Drinks] this is not the right Bottle, yet— [Drinks] no no—here. Gives her the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: You said, that with the Red Cork Sir. Goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
I meant the Blew, — I know not what I say, — in fine, my Lady let us marry her out of hand, for she is fall'n, fall'n to Perdition; she understands more wickedness then had she been bred in a profane Nunnery —a Court, or a Play-house,
Enter Maundy. [Drinks] —therefore let's Marry her instantly—out of hand, [Drinks] Misfortune on Misfortune, [Drinks] — but Patience is a wonderfull Vertue, [Drinks] —ha—this is very Comfortable, —very Consoling, —I profess if it were not for these Creature ravishing Comforts, sometimes, a Man were a very odd sort of an Animal [Drinks] but ah—see how all things were ordain'd for the use and comfort of man [Drinks.]

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I like this well; Ah Sir 'tis very true, therefore receive it plentifully and thankfully.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Drinks Ingeniously —it hath made me marvellous lightsome, —I profess it hath a very notable Faculty, —very knavish—and as—it were—waggish, —but —hah— what have we there on the Table? a Sword and Hat?
Sees Wittmore's Sword and Hat on the Table which he had forgot.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Curse on my Dullness, —oh —these Sir, they are Mr. Fainloves— he being so soon to be Marry'd, and being straitned for time, sent these to Maundy to be new trim'd with
Ribbon Sir—that's all,—take 'em away you naughty Baggage, must I have mens things seen in my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Nay nay, be not angry my little Rogue, I like the young mans frugality well, — go go your ways, —get you gon—and finefy your knacks, and tranghams, and do your business —goe.—
Smiling on Maundy, gently beating her with his hand: she goes out, he bolts the door after her, and sits down on the Beds feet.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Heavens, what means he!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Come hither to me my little Apes face, —come —come I say—what must I come fetch you? —Catch her, catch her, catch her—catch her, catch her, catch her. Running after her.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh Sir I am so ill I can hardly stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I'le make ye well, come hither ye Monky face, did it, did it, did it? alas for it, a poor silly fools face, dive it a blow and I'le beat it.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: You neglect your Devotion Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: No no, no Prayer to day my little Rascall, —no Prayer to day —poor Gogle's sick — come hither—why you Refractory Baggage you, come or I shall touze you, ingenuously I shall, tom tom or I'le whip it.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Have you forgot your Daughter Sir? and your disgrace?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A fiddle on my Daughter, she's a Chick of the old Cock I profess, I was just such another wag when young, —but she shall be marry'd to morrow, a good Cloke for her knavery; therefore come your ways, ye wag, we'le take a nap together, good faith my little Harlot I mean thee no harm.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: No o' my Conscience. —

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why then, why then you little Mungrel?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: His precise worship is as it were disguis'd, the outward man is overtaken — pray Sir lye down, and I'le come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Away you wag, will you? will you—catch her there, catch her.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
I will indeed —death there's no getting from him, —pray lye down—and I'le cover thee close enough I'le warrant thee. — Aside. He lyes down, she covers him.
Had ever Lovers such spightfull Luck? hah —surely he sleeps, bless the mistaken Bottle—Aye, he sleeps, —whist, Wittmore.—

div.stage: He coming out falls: pulls the Chair down, Sir Patient flings open the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Plague of my over Care, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What's that, what noise is that? let me see, we are not safe, lock up the doors, what's the matter, what Thunder Clap was that? Wittmore runs under the Bed: she runs to Sir Patient and holds him in his Bed.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Pray Sir lye still, 'twas I was only going to sit down, and a suddain giddiness took me in my head which made me fall and with me the Chair, there is no danger near ye Sir—I was just coming to sleep by you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Go you 're a flattering Huswife, goe, Catch her, catch her—catch her.— Lyes down, she covers him.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh how I tremble at the dismal apprehension of being discovered, had I secur'd my self of the Eight thousand Pound, I wou'd not value Wittmores being seen, but now to be found out wou'd call my Wit in question, for 'tis the fortunate alone are wise.— Wittmore peeps from under the Bed: she goes softly to the door to open it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Was ever man so Plagu'd? —hah— what's this? — confound my tell-tale Watch, the Larum goes, and there▪ no getting to't to silence it; —Damn'd Misfortune!

div.stage: Sir Patient rises and flings open the Curtains.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, what's that!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Heavens! what's the matter? we are destin'd to discovery.
She runs to Sir Patient, and leaves the door still fast.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What's that I say, what's that? let me see, let me see, what ringing's that, oh let me see what 'tis.

div.stage: Strives to get up, she holds him down.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh now I see my fate's inevitable, alas that ever I was born to see't. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Death she'le tell him I am here! nay he must know't, a Pox of all invention and Mechanicks, and he were damn'd that first contriv'd a Watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, dost weep, —why dost weep? I say what noise is that? what ringing? hah▪—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: 'Tis that, 'tis that my dear that makes me weep, alas I never hear this fatall Noise but some dear friend dyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, dyes! oh that must be I, Aye Aye, oh.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: I've heard it Sir this two dayes, but wou'd not tell you of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah! heard it these two dayes? oh, what is't, a death-watch? —hah.—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Aye Sir, a death-watch, a certain Larum death-watch, a thing that has warn'd our Family this hundred years, oh —I'me the most undone Woman.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: A blessing on her for a dear dissembling Gilt —death and the Devil, will it never cease?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A death-watch? ah, 'tis so, I've often heard of these things —methinks it sounds as if 'twere under the Bed.—

div.stage: Offers to look, she holds him.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: You think so Sir, but that 'tis about the Bed is my grief, it therefore threatens you: oh wretched Woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I'me too happy in a wife to live long: well, I will settle my House at Hogsdowne with the Land about it, which is 500 l. a year upon thee, live or dye, —do not grieve.—

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Oh I never had more cause, come try to sleep; your fate may be diverted —whilst I'le to prayers for your dear health, — I have almost run Covers him, draws the Curtains. out all my stock of Hypocrisie, and that hated Art now fails me, —no all ye Powers that favour distrest Lovers, assist us now, and I'le provide against your future Malice.
She makes signes to Wittmore, he peeps.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I'me impatient of Freedom, yet so much happiness as I but now injoy'd without this part of Suffering had made me too blest, — Death and Damnation! what curst luck have I?

div.stage: Makes signs to her to open the Door: whilst he creeps softly from under the Bed to the Table, by which going to raise himself he pulls down all the Dressing things: at the same instant Sir Patient leaps from the Bed, and she returns from the door and sits on Wittmores back as he lies on his hands and knees, and makes as if she swounded.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What's the matter! what's the matter! has Satan broke his everlasting Chain and got loose abroad to Plague poor Mortalls? hah — what's the matter? Runs to his Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh help, I dye, — I faint—run down and call for help.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My Lady dying? oh she's gon, she faints, — what ho, who waits? Cries and baules.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh, go down and bring me help, the door is lockt, — they cannot hear ye — oh — I goe — I dye.—

div.stage: He opens the door and calls help, help.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Damn him! there's no escaping without I kill the Dog.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Lye still or we are undone. —

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Hah, discover'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Help, help my Lady dies. —

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Oh I perceive how 'tis — Alas she's dead, quite gone, oh rub her temples Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh I'me undone then, — [Weeps] oh my dear, my Vertuous Lady? —

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Oh where's my Husband, my dearest Husband — oh bring him near me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I'me here my Excellent Lady. —

div.stage: She takes him about the neck and raises her self up, gives Wittmore a little kick behind.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Oh the dear Lovely Hypocrite, was ever Man so near discovery? — Goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh how hard she presses my head to her Bosome!

sp.speaker: Maun.
sp.p: Ah, that grasping hard Sir, is a very bad sign.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How does my good, my dearest Lady Fancy?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Something better now, give me more Air, —that dismall Larum Death-watch had almost kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah Precious Creature, how she afflicts her self for me, — come let's walk into the Dining room, 'tis more Airie, from thence into my Study, and make thy self Mistress of that Fortune I have design'd thee, thou best of Women. Exeunt, Leading her.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I. A Table, and Six Chairs.
div.stage: Enter Isabella Reading a Letter, Betty tricking her.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: HHow came you by this Letter?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Miss Fanny receiv'd it by a string from his Window, by which he took up that you writ to him this morning.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What means this nicety? forbear I say. —

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: You cannot be too fine upon your VVedding day.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Thou art mistaken, leave me, — whatever he says here to satisfy my jealousy, I am confirm'd that he was false, yet this assurance to free me from this intended marriage, makes me resolve to pardon him however guilty. —
Enter Wittmore. How now! what means this insolence? How dare you having so lately made your guilty approaches, venture again into my presence?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why? Is there any danger, but what's so visible, in those fair eyes?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And there may lie enough Sir, when they're angry. By what Authority do you make this sawcy visit?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: That of a Husband Madam, I came to congratulate the mighty joy this day will bring you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thou dar'st not marry me, there will be danger in't.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why sure you do not carry Death in your imbraces, I find no Terrour in that lovely shape, no Daggers in that pretty scornfull look; that breath that utters so much Anger now, last night was sweet as new-blown Roses are, — and spoke such words, so tender and so kind.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And canst thou think they were address'd to thee?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: No, nor cou'd the shade of Night hide the confusion which disorder'd you, at the discovery that I was not he, the blessed he you look'd for.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Leave me, thou hated object of my Soul.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: This will not serve your turn, for I must marry you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then thou art a fool, and drawest thy ruin on; why I will hate thee, — hate thee most extreamly.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: That will not anger me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why, I will never let thee touch me, not kiss my hand, not come into my sight.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Are there no other women, kind, fair, and to be purchas'd? he cannot starve for Beauty in this age, that has a stock to buy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why, I will Cuckold thee, look to't; I will most damnably.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: So wou'd you, had you lov'd me, in a year or two; therefore like a kind civil Husband I've made provision for you, a friend, and one I dare trust my Honour with, — 'tis Mr. Knowel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Lodwick! What Devil brought that name to his knowledge? — canst thou know him, and yet dare hope to marry me?

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: We have agree'd it, and on these conditions.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thou basely injurest him, he cannot do a deed he ought to blush for: Lodwick do this! Oh do not credit it, — prethee be just and kind for thy own Honours sake, be quickly so, the hasty minutes fly, and will anon make up the fatal hour that will undoe me.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: 'Tis true, within an hour you must submit to Hymen, there's no avoiding it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nay then be gone my poor submissive Prayers, and all that dull Obedience custom had made us slaves to, — do, Sacrifice me, lead me to the Altar, and see if all the holy mystick words can Conjure from me the consenting syllable: No, I will not add one word to make the charm compleat, but stand as silent in th'inchantiug Circle, as if the Priests were raising Devils there.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Enough, enough, my charming Isabella, I am confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Lodwick! what good Angel conducted thee hither?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: E'en honest Charles VVittmore here, thy friend and mine, no Bug-bear Lover he!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: VVittmore! that friend I've often heard thee name? now some kind mischief on him, he has so frighted me, I scarce can bring my sense to so much order, to thank him that he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Thou shalt defer that payment to more leisure, we're men of business now. My Mother knowing of a Consultation of Physicians which your Father has this day appointed to meet at his house, has brib'd Monsieur Turboone his French Doctor in Pension, to admit of a Doctor or two of her recommending, who shall amuse him with discourse till we get our selves married; and to make it the more ridiculous, I will release Sir Credulous from the Basket, I saw it in the Hall as I came through, we shall have need of the fool.
Ex. Witt.

div.stage: Enter Wittmore pulling in the Basket.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: 'Twill do well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir Credulous how is't man? Opens the Basket.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What am not I at the Carriers yet? — Oh Lodwick thy hand, I'me almost poison'd — this Basket wants airing extreamly, it smells like an old Ladies Wedding-Gown of my acquaintance, — but what's the danger past, man?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, but there's a necessity of your being for some time disguis'd to act a Physician.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How! a Physician! that I can easily do, for I understand Simples.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That's not material, so you can but Banter well, be very Grave, and put on a starch'd countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Banter? what's that, man?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why Sir, talking very much, and meaning just nothing; be full of words without any connexion, sence, or conclusion: come in with me, and I'le instruct you farther.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Pshaw, is that all, say no more ont, I'le do't, let me alone for Bantering, — but this same damn'd Rival? —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
He's now watching for you without, and means to souce upon you, but trust to me for your security, come away, I have your habit ready. [Goes out.] — This day shall make thee mine, Dear Isabella.—
Ex. Lod. and Witt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Patient, and Leander, and Roger.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Marry Lucretia! is there no Woman in the City fit
for you but the Daughter of the most notorious fantastical Lady within the Walls?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Yet that fantastical Lady you thought fit for a Wife for me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Yes Sir, Foppery with Money had been something, but a poor Fop, hang't 'tis abominable.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Pray hear me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sirrah, Sirrah, you're a Jackanapes, ingenuously you are Sir, Marry Lucretia quoth he!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: If it were so Sir, where's her fault?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why Mr. Coxcombe, all over. Did I with so much care endeavour to marry thee to the Mother, only to give thee opportunity with Lucretia?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This Anger shews your great concern for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: For my name I am, but 'twere no matter if thou wert hang'd, and thou deservest it for thy lewd Cavaliering Opinion, — they say thou art a Papist too, or at least a Church of England Man, and I profess there's not a pin to chuse, — Marry Lucretia!

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Were I querimonious, I shou'd resent the affront this Balatroon has offer'd me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Dear Madam, for my sake do not anger him now.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Upon my Honour you are very free with my Daughter Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How! she here! now for a Peal from her eternal Clapper, I had rather be confin'd to an Iron-mill.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Sure Lucretia merits a Husband of as much worth as your Nephew Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A better, Madam, for he's the lewdest Hector in the Town, he has all the Vices of youth, Whoring, Swearing, Drinking, Damning, Fighting, — and a Thousand more, numberless and nameless.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Time Sir may make him more abstemious.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh never Madam! 'tis in's Nature, he was born with it, he's given over to Reprobation, 'tis bred i'th' bone, — he's lost.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This is the first good Office that ever he did me.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: What think you Sir, if in defiance of your Inurbanity, I take him with all these faults my self?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How Madam!

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Without more Ambages Sir, I have consider'd your former desires, and have consented to marry him, notwithstanding your exprobrations.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pat.
sp.p: May I believe this Madam, and has your Ladiship that goodness! —and hast thou my Boy so much Wit? why this is something now, — well he was ever the best and sweetest natur'd youth, — why what a notable wag's this? and is it true my Boy, hah?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I had told you so before had you permitted me to speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Well Madam, he is onely sit for your excellent Ladiship, he is the prettiest civillest Lad! — well go thy ways; I shall never see the like of thee, no— Ingeniously the Boy's made for ever, Two thousand Pounds a year besides Money, Plate, and Jewels, made for ever. — Well Madam, the satisfaction I take in this Alliance, has made me resolve to give him immediately my Writings of all my Land in Berkshire, Five hundred Pounds a year Madam, and I wou'd have you Married this morning with my Daughter, so one Dinner and one Rejoycing will serve both.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: That Sir, we have already agree'd upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Well I'le fetch the Writings. Come Isabella, I'le not trust you out of my sight to day.
Ex. Sir Pat. and Isab.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: VVell then Madam, you are resolv'd upon this business of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Was it not concluded between us Sir this morning? and at the near approach do you begin to fear?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Nothing Madam, since I'me convinc'd of your goodness.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: You flatter Sir, this is meer Adulation.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: No, I am that wild Extravagant my Uncle render'd me, and cannot live confin'd.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: To one Woman you mean? I shall not stand with you for a Mistress or two, I hate a dull morose unfashionable Blockhead to my Husband, nor shall I be the first example of a suffering Wise Sir; Women were created poor obedient things.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: And can you be content to spare me five or six nights in a week?

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh you're too reasonable.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: And for the rest, if I get drunk, perhaps I'le give to you: yet in my Drink I'me damn'd ill natur'd too, and may neglect my duty, perhaps shall be so wicked to call you cunning, deceitful, gilting, base, and swear you have undone me, swear you have ravish'd from my faithful heart, all that cou'd make it blest or happy.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: How now▪ Lucretia?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Oh Madam, give me leave to kneel before, and tell you if you pursue the Cruelty I hear you're going to commit, I am the most lost, most wretched Maid that breaths; We two have plighted faiths, and shou'd you marry him, 'twere so to sin as Heaven wou'd never pardon.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Rise fool.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
