sp.l: Never, till you have given me back Leander, or leave to live no more, — pray kill me Madam; and the same
Flowers that deck your Nuptial-bed,
Shall serve to strow my Herse, when I shall lie
A dead cold witness of your Tyranny.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p:
Rise, I still design'd him yours. — I saw with pleasure Sir, your reclination from my addresses, — I have prov'd both your Passions, and 'twere unkind not to Crown 'em with the due praemium of each others merits.
Gives her to Lean.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Can Heaven and you agree to be so bountiful?

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Be not amaz'd at this turn, Rotat omne fatum, — but no more, — keep still that mask of Love we first put on, till you have gain'd the Writings, for I have no joy beyond cheating that filthy Uncle of thine, — Lucretia wipe your eyes, and prepare for Hymen, the hour draws near. Thalessio, Thalessio! as the Romans cry'd.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: May you be still admir'd as you deserve!

div.stage: Enter Sir Patient with Writings, and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How Madam Lucretia, and in tears!

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: A little disgusted Sir, with her Father-in-law, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Oh is that all, hold up thy head Sweet-heart, thy turn's next, — here Madam, I surrender my Title, with these Writings,
and with 'em my Joy, my Life, my Darling, my Leander, — now let's away, where's Mr. Fain-love?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: He's but stept into Cheapside to fit the Ring Sir, and will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I have business anon about Eleven of the Clock, a Consultation of Physicians to confer about this Carkase of mine.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Physicians Sir, what to doe?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: To do! why to take their advice Sir, and to follow it.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: For what I beseech you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why Sir for my health.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I believe you are not sick Sir, — unless they make you so.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: They make me so!— do you hear him Madam, — am not I sick Sir? not I, Sir Patient Fancy sick?

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: He'le destroy my design, — how Mr. Fancy, not Sir Patient sick? or must he be incinerated before you'le credit it?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Aye Madam, I want but dying to undeceive him, and yet I am not sick!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Sir I love your life, and wou'd not have you die with Fancy and Conceit. —

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Fancy and Conceit! do but observe him Madam, — what do ye mean Sir, by Fancy and Conceit?

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: He'le ruin all, — why Sir, — he means—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Nay let him alone, let him alone, (with your Ladiships pardon)—come Sir, — Fancy and Conceit, I take it, was the Question in debate, —

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I cannot prove this to you Sir, by force of Argument, but by demonstration I will, if you will banish all your couzening Quacks, and take my wholesome advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Do but hear him Madam, not prove it.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Sir he means nothing, — not sick! alas Sir you're very sick.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, your Ladiship is a Lady of profound knowledge — why have I not had the advice of all the Doctors in England, and have I not been in continual Physick this Twenty years, — and yet I am not sick! ask my dear Lady Sir, how sick I am, she can inform you. La. Kno. goes and talks to Isab.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: She does her endeavour Sir, to keep up the humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How Sir!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: She wishes you dead Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What said the Rascal? wishes me dead!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Sir she hates you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How! hate me! what my Lady hate me?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: She abuses your Love, plays tricks with ye, and cheats ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Was ever so prophane a wretch! what, you will not prove this neither?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Yes, by demonstration too.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why thou sawcie Varlet, Sirrah, Sirrah thank my Lady here I do not cudgel thee, — well I will settle the rest of my Estate upon her to morrow, I will Sir, — and thank God you have what you have Sir, make much on't.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, 'tis not my single opinion, but the whole City takes notice on't, that I tell it you Sir is the effects of my Duty not Interest, pray give me leave to prove this to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What you are at your Demonstration again?—come — let's hear.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Why Sir, —give her frequent opportunities, —and then surprise her, — or, —by pretending to settle all upon her, — give her your Power, and see if she do not turn you out of doors, — or —by feigning you are sick to death —or indeed by dying.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, — this indeed is Demonstration, I take it.— Pulls off his Hat.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I mean but feigning Sir, and be a witness your self of her sorrow, or contempt.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Pauses —Hah—hum,—why ingeniously this may be a very pretty Project, — well Sir, suppose I follow your advice? — nay I profess I will do so, not to try her Faith, but to have the pleasure to hear her Conjugal Lamentations, feel her Tears bedew my Face, and her sweet Mouth kissing my Cheeks a thousand times, verily a wonderful comfort, — and then Sir, what becomes of your Demonstration.—
Enter Wittmore with the Ring.
Oh, — Mr. Fain-love, come come you're tardy, let us away to Church.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sir here is Doctor Turboone, and those other Doctors your Worship expected.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: The Doctors already! —well bring 'em up, come Madam, we have waited for your Ladiship, — bring up the Doctors Roger.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Wittmore, I have now brought that design to a happy conclusion for which I married this formal Ass, I'le tell thee more anon, — we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh Lodwick's come.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, Monsieur Turboon, Fat Doctor, Amsterdam, Leyden, Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Doctor Turboon your Servant, I expected you not this two hours.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Nor had ee com Sir, bot for dese wordy Gentelmen, whos affairs wode not permit dem to com at your hour.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Are they English pray?

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p:
Dis is Sir, — [pointing to Lod.] an admirable Physician, and a rare Astrologer. —Dis speaks good English, bot a Collender born.
points to Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What a pox does the Fellow call me a Cullender?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He means a High-Dutch man of the Town of Collen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sir I have heard of your Fame, —Doctor pray entertain these Gentlemen till my return, I'le be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I hope you go not forth to day? Gazing on his Face.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Not far, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: There is a certain Star has rul'd this two daies Sir, of a very malignant Influence to persons of your Complexion and constitution, —let me see —within this two hours and six Minutes, its Malice will be spent, till then it will be fatall.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hum, reign'd this two days? —I profess and things have gon very cross with me this two daies, —a notable man this.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Oh a very Profound Astrologer Sir, upon my Honour I know him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But this is an affair of that importance Sir—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If it be more than health or Life, I beg your Pardon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Nay no offence Sir I beseech you, I'le stay Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: How! Sir Patient not see us Married?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: You shall excuse me Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: This was lucky, oh Madam wou'd you have my Dear venture out, when a malignant Star reigns! not for the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
No I'le not stir, had it been any Star but a malignant Star, I had waited on your Ladiship. But these malignant Stars are very Pernicious stars. Nephew, take my Lady Knowell; Mr. Fain-love my Daughter, and Bartholomew do you conduct my Lady, the Parson stays for you, and the Coaches are at the door.
Exeunt Lady Knowell, Leander, Wittmore and Isab. Lady Fancy and Bartholomew.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady has sent for you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I'le be with you presently, Sir Credulous be sure you lug him by the Ears, with any sort of stuff, till my return, I'le send you a friend to keep you in Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Please you to sit Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p:
Please you Sir.
To Sir Cred. who bows and runs back.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh Lord sweet Sir, I hope you do not take me— Nay I beseech you Noble Sir —Reverend Sir.

sp.speaker: Leyd.
sp.p: By no means Sir, a stranger.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I beseech you —Scavantissimi Doctores, —incomparable Sir, —and you— or you.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: Introth Sir, these Complements are needless, I am something corpulent and love my ease. Sits.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Generous Sir, you say well, therefore Conlicentia, as the Grecians have it. Sits.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: —Brother.—

sp.speaker: Leyd.
sp.p: Nay good Brother, —Sir Patient.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ingeniously, not before you, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Leyd.
sp.p: Excuse me Sir, an Alderman, and a Knight.—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Both below the least of the Learned Society.

sp.speaker: Leyd.
sp.p: Since you will have it so. All sit and cry hum, —and look gravely.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Hum — hum, most Worthy, and most Renouned— Medicinae Professores, qui hic assemblati estis; & vos altra Mesioris, I am now going to make a Motion for the Publick good of us all, but will do nothing without your Doctorships Approbation.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Judiciously concluded.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: The question then is, Reverentissimi Doctores, whether— for mark me, I come to the matter in hand, hating long Circumstances of words; there being no necessity as our Learned Brother Rabalis observes in that most notorious Treatise of his call'd Garagantua, there is says he, no necessity of going over the Hedg when the Path lies fair before ye; therefore as I said before, I now say again coming to my Question, for as that admirable Welch Divine says in that so famous Sermon of his, upon her Creat Cranfather Hadam and her Creat Cranmother Heeve concerning the Happell, —and her will warrant her, her will keep to her Text still, —so I stick close to my question, which is Illustrissimi Doctores, whether it be not necessary to the Affair in hand — to take—a Bottle, and if your Doctorships are of my opinion— hold up your Thumbs. All hold up their Thumbs. —Look Sir, you observe the Votes of the Learned Cabalists.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Which shall be put in Act forthwith — I like this man well, he does nothing without mature deliberation. Goes ont.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: By your leaves Gentlemen, —Sir Crodulous— Whispers.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh —'tis Lodwicks Friend, the Rascall's drest like Vanderbergen in the Strand: —Sir Patient— pray know this glorious Doctor Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: A Doctor Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Doctor Sir, yes, and as Eloquent a Doctor, Sir, as ever set Bill to Post, why 'tis — the incomparable — Brunswick, high Dutch Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: You're welcome Sir, —Pray sit; ah—well Sir you are come to visit a very Crazy sickly Person Sir.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Pray let me feel your Pulse Sir, — what think you Gentlemen, is he not very far gone? — Feels his pulse, they all feel.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ah far, far, — Pray Sir, have you not a certain wambling Pain in your Stomach Sir, as it were Sir a—a Pain Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh very great Sir, especially in a Morning Fasting.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I knew it by your stinking breath Sir, —and are you not troubled with a pain in your Head Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: In my Head Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
I mean a—kind of a —Pain, — a kind of a — Vertigo as the Latins call it, and a Whirligigoustiphon as the Greeks
have it, which signifies in English Sir, a Dizzie-swimming kind—of a de ye see—a thing—that—a—you understand me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh intolerable, intolerable, —why this is a rare man.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p:
Your reason Sir for that?
To Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: My reason Sir? why my reason Sir is this, Haly the Moore, and Rabbie Isack and some thousands more of learned Dutchmen observe your dull wall Eye and your Whir—Whirligigoustiphon, to be inseparable.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: A most Learned reason.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: Oh Sir inseparable.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: And have you not a kind of a—something —de ye mark me, when you make water, a kind of a stopping—and— a—de ye conceive me, I have forgot the English term Sir, but in Latin 'tis a Stronggullionibus.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Oh Sir most extreamly, 'tis that which makes me desperate Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Your ugly Face is an infallible sign, your Dysurie as the Arabicks call it, and your Ill-favor'd Countenance, are constant Relatives.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Constant, constant.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Pray how do you eat, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ah Sir, there's my distraction. Alas Sir, I have the weakest stomach—I do not make above four Meals a day, and then indeed I eat heartily— but alas what's that to eating to live,—nothing Sir nothing.—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Poor heart I pity him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: And between meals, good Wine, Sweet-meats, Candles, —Cordialls and Mirabilises, to keep up my fainting Spirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Pox of his Aldermanship: an the whole Bench were such notable swingers, twou'd Famish the City sooner than a Siege.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Brothers what do you think of this man?

sp.speaker: Leyd.
sp.p: Think Sir? I think his Case is desperate.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Shaw Sir, we shall soon rectify the quiblets and quillities of his bloud if he observes our directions and diet, which is to eat but once in four or five daies.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How Sir, eat but once in four or five daies! such a dyet Sir wou'd kill me, alas Sir kill me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Oh no Sir, no, for look ye Sir the Case is thus, do ye mind me—so that the business lying so obvious de ye see, there
is a certain method do ye mark me— in a—Now Sir when a man goes about to alter the course of Nature, —the case is very plain, you may as well arrest the Chariot of the Sun, or alter the Eclipses of the Moon, for Sir this being of another Nature, the Nature of it is to be unnaturall, you conceive me Sir? — therefore we must crave your absence Sir for a few Minutes, till we have debated this great Affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
With all my heart Sir, since my case is so desperate, a few hours were not too much.
Ex. Sir Patient.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now Sir, my Service to you. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Oh living heart! what do all these men do in our house? sure they are a sort of New-fashon'd Conventiclers: —I'le hear 'em preach. They drink round the while.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Sir my service to you, and to your good Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Again to you Sir, not forgetting your Daughters: they are fine Women Sir, let Scandal do its worst. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: To our better trading Sir.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Faith it goes but badly on, I had the weekly Bill and 'twas a very thin Mortality, some of the better sort dye indeed that have good round Fees to give.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Verily I have not kill'd above my five or six this week.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: How Sir kill'd?

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Kill'd Sir! ever whilst you live, especially those who have the grand Verole, for 'tis not for a man's Credit to let the Patient want an Eye or a Nose, or some other ting, I have kill'd ye my five or six dozen a week —but times are hard.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: I grant ye Sir, your Poor for Experiment, and improvement of Knowledge, and to say truth there ought to be such Scavengers as we to sweep away the Rubbish of the Nation.

div.stage: Sir Cred. and Fat seeming in discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nay an you talk of a beast; My service to you Sir— [Drinks] Aye, I lost the finest beast of a Mare in all Devonshire.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: And I the finest Spaniel Sir.

div.stage: Here they all talk together till you come to —purpose Sir.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Pray what news is there stirring?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I am one of those fools that never regard whether Lewes or Philip have the better or the worst.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Peace is a great blessing Sir, a very great blessing.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: You are i'th' right Sir, and so my service to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Well, Sir, Stetin held out Nobly, though the Gazetts are various.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: There's a world of men kill'd they say, why what a shame 'tis so many thousand should dye without the help of a Physician.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Hang 'em they were poor Rogues and not worth our killing, my service to you Sir, they'le serve to fill up Trenches.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Spaniell Sir! no man breathing understands Dogs and Horses better then my self.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: Your Pardon for that Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: For look ye Sir, I'le tell you the Nature of Dogs and Horses.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: So can my Groom and Dog-keeper, but what's this t'th' purpose Sir? Here they leave off.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: To th' purpose Sir, good Mr. Hedleburgh do you understand what's to th' purpose? you're a Dutch Butter-ferkin, a Kilderkin, a Double Jugg.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: You're an ignorant Blockhead Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You lye Sir, and there I was with you again.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: What, quarrelling, men of your gravity and Profession!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: That is to say Fools and Knaves, pray how long is't since you left Toping and Naping, for Quacking, good Brother Cater-tray, —but let that pass, for I'le have my Humour, and therefore will quarrell with no man, and so I drink.—

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: —But what's all this to the Patient, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Aye—the Wine's all out, —and quarrells apart Gentlemen as you say, what do ye think of our Patient, for something I conceive necessary to be said for our Fees.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: I think that unless he follows our Prescriptions he's a dead man.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Aye Sir a dead man.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p:
Please you to write Sir, you seem the youngest Doctor.
To Amst.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Your Pardon Sir, I conceive there may be younger Doctors then I at the board.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A fine Punctilio this, when a man lies a dying—Sir Aside. you shall excuse me, I have been a Doctor this 7 years.

div.stage: They shove the pen and paper from one to the other.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: I Commenc't at Paris twenty years agoe.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: And I at Leyden, almost as long since.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: And I at Bercelona thirty.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: And I at Padua, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: You at Padua?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Yes Sir I at Padua, why what a Pox do ye think I never was beyond-sea?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: However Sir you are the youngest Doctor and must write.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I will not lose an Inch of my Dignity.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Nor I. Put the paper from each other

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Death what Rascalls are these?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Give me the pen—here's adoe about your Paduas and Punctilioes. Sets himself to write.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Every Morning a Dose of my Pills Merda quecrusticon, or the Amicable Pill.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Fasting?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: Every hour Sixscore drops of Adminicula Vitae.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
— Fasting too?
Sir Credulous writes still.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: At Night twelve Cordiall Pills, Gallimofriticus.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Let bloud once a week, a Glister once a day.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Cry Mercy Sir, you're a French man — After his first sleep, threescore restorative Pills call'd Cheatus Redivivus.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —And lastly, fifteen spoonfulls of my Aqua Tetrachymagogon, as often as 'tis necessary, little or no Breakfast, less Dinner, and go supperless to bed.

sp.speaker: Fat D.
sp.p: Hum, your Aqua Tetrachymagogon?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Yes Sir, my Tetrachymagogon, for look ye do ye see Sir, I cur'd the Arch-Duke of Strumbulo, of a Gondileero, of which he dy'd, with this very Aqua Tetrachymagogon.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen am I not an intruder?

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.p: Sir we have duly consider'd the state of your Body: and are now about the order and method you are to observe.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.p: Aye this distemper will be the occasion of his death.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Hold Brothers, I do not say the occasion of his death: But the occasional cause of his death.
Sir Pat. reads the Bill.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why here's no time allow'd for eating Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Amst.
sp.p: Sir we'le justify this Prescription to the whole College.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.p: If he will not follow it, let him dye.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye let him dye.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What have you consulted without me Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and find it absolutely necessary for my health Sir, I shou'd be starv'd: and yet you say I am not sick Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Very well, very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: No Breakfast, no Dinner, no Supper?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Little or none, but none's best.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But Gentlemen consider, no small thing?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
Sir, you must write for your Fee.
To Lod.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now I think on't Sir you may eat, [writes] a Rosted-Pippin cold upon a Vine leaf, at night.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Do you see Sir, what damn'd canting Rascals these Doctors are?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Aye, aye, if all Doctors were such, ingeniously I shou'd soon be weary of Physick.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Give 'em their Fees Sir, and send 'em to the Devil for a company of Cheats.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Truth is, there's no faith in 'em, — well I thank you for your care and pains. gives 'em Fees.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sir if you have any occasion for me, I live at the Red colour'd Lanthorn, with Eleven Candles in't, in the Strand; where you may come in privately, and need not be ashamed, I having no Creature in my House but my self, and my whole Family. —
sp.l: Ick quam Van Neder Landt te spreken
End helpen Van Pocken end ander gebreken.
sp.p: That's a top of my Bill sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Lord, Sir Father, why did you give 'em money?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: For talking nonsense this hour or two upon his distemper.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Oh lemini Sir, they did not talk one word of you, but of Dogs, and Horses, and of killing folks, and of their Wives and Daughters; and when the Wine was all out, they said they wou'd say something for their Fees.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Say you so? — Knaves, Rogues, Cheats, Murderers! I'le be reveng'd on 'em all, — I'le ne're be sick again, — or if I
be I'le die honestly of my self without the assistance of such Rascals, — go, get you gone, —
To Fan. who goes out.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: A happy resolution, wou'd you wou'd be so kind to your self as to make a trial of your Lady too, and if she prove true, 'twill make some kind of amends for your so long being couzen'd this way.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I'le about it, this very minute about it, — give me a Chair.— He sits.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: So, settle your self well, disorder your Hair, — throw away your Cane, Hat, and Gloves, — stare and rowl your eyes, squeez your Face into Convulsions, — clutch your hands, — make your Stomach heave,—so, very well,— now let me alone for the rest, — Oh, help, help my Lady, my Aunt, for Heavens sake help, — come all and see him die. Weeps.

div.stage: Enter Wittmore, Lady Fancy, Isabella, Lucretia, Lady Knowell, and Roger.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Leander, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: See Madam, see my Uncle in the Agonies of Death.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: My dearest Husband dying, Oh! Weeps.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How hard he struggles with departing life!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Father, dear Father, must I in one day receive a blessing with so great a curse? Oh, — he's just going Madam. — Weeps.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Let me o'retake him in the shades below, why do you hold me, can I live without him? —do I dissemble well?—

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Not live without me! — do you hear that sirrah?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Pray Mark the end on't Sir, — feign,— feign,—

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: We left him well, how came he thus o'th' suddain?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I fear 'tis an Apoplexy Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Run, run for his Physician! but do not stir a foot.
Aside to Roger. Look up and speak but one kind word to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: What cries are these that stop me on my way?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: They're mine,— your Ladies, — oh surely he'le recover, [Aside] your most obedient Wife's.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: My Wife's my Heir, my sole Executrix.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
Hah, is he in's senses? [Aside to Witt.] Oh my dear
Love, my Life, my Joy, my all, [Cryes] oh let me goe; I will not live without him.
Seems to faint in Wittmore's Armes. All run about her.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Do ye hear that sirrah?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Have yet a little patience, die away,—very well — Oh he's gone, — quite gone. La. Fa. swounds.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Look to my Lady there, [swounds again] — sure she can but counterfeit. [Aside.] They all go about her.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, my Lady dying!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p:
Sir I beseech you wait the event; Death! the cunning Devil will dissemble too long and spoil all, —here— carry the dead Corps of my dearest Uncle to his Chamber. Nurse to your care I commit him now.
Exeunt with Sir Pat. in a Chair.

div.stage: All follow but Wittmore; who going the other way meets Sir Credulous and Lodwick, as before.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Lodwick! the strangest unexpected News, Sir Patient's Dead!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: How, dead! we have play'd the Physicians to good purpose i'faith, and kill'd the man before we administred our Physick.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Egad I fear so indeed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: As a Herring, and 'twill be dangerous to keep these habits longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Dangerous! Zoz man we shall all be hang'd, why our very Bill dispatch'd him, and our Hands are to't, — oh, I'le confess all.— Offers to goe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Death Sir, I'le cut your Throat if you stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me hang'd for company Gentlemen? Oh where shall I hide my self, or how come at my cloaths?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: We have no time for that, go get you into your Basket again, and lie snug, till I have convey'd you safe away, —or I'le abandon you. — [Aside to him.] 'Tis not necessary he shou'd be seen yet, he may spoil Leander's Plot. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh thank ye dear Lodwick, — let me escape this bout, and if ever the Fool turn Physician again, may he be choak'd with his own Tetrachymagogon.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
Go hast and undress you, whilst I'le to Lucia.
Ex. Lod.

div.stage: As Wittmore is going out at one Door, Enter Sir Patient and Leander at the other.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Hah, Wittmore there! he must not see my Uncle yet.

div.stage: Puts Sir Pat. back. Ex. Witt.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Nay Sir, never detain me, I'le to my Lady, is this your Demonstration? —was ever so vertuous a Lady? — Well I'le to her, and console her poor heart, ah the joy 'twill bring her to see my Resurrection! — I long to surprize her.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p:
Hold Sir, I think she's coming, — blest sight, and with her Wittmore!
Puts Sir Pat. back to the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, what's this?

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Now my dear VVitmore, claim thy Rites of Love without controll, without the contradiction of wretched Poverty or Jealousy: Now, undisguis'd thou maist approach my Bed, and reign o're all my Pleasures and my Fortunes, of which this minute I create thee Lord.
And thus begin my Homage.— Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Sure 'tis some Fiend! This cannot be my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: 'Tis something uncivil before your face Sir, to do this.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Thou wondrous kind, and wondrous Beautiful, that Power that made thee with so many Charms, gave me a Soul sit onely to adore 'em; nor wert thou destin'd to another's Arms, but to be render'd still more fit for mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, is not that Fain-love? Isabella's Husband? Oh Villain! Villain! I will renounce my Sense and my Religion.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.l: Anothers Armes! Oh call not those hated thoughts to my remembrance,
Lest it destroy that kindly heat within me,
Which thou canst onely raise, and still maintain.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Oh Woman! Woman! damn'd dissembling Woman!

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Come let me lead thee to that Mass of Gold he gave me to be despis'd:
And which I render thee, my lovely Conquerour,

As the first Tribute of my Glorious Servitude, — Draw in
the Basket which I told you of, and is amongst the Rubbish in the Hall, [Ex. Wittmore.] That which the Slave so many years was toiling for, I in one moment barter for a Kiss, as Earnest of our future Joys.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Was ever so prodigal a Harlot? was this the Saint? was this the most tender Consort that ever man had?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: No in good faith Sir.

div.stage: Enter Wittmore pulling in the Basket.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: This is it with a direction on't to thee, whither I design'd to send it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Good morrow to the day, and next the Gold, open the Shrine, that I may see my Saint—hail the Worlds Soul—

div.stage: Opens the Basket, Sir Cred. starts up.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: O Heavens! what thing art thou?

sp.speaker: Sir. Cred.
sp.p: O Pardon, Pardon sweet Lady, I confess I had a hand in't.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: In what, thou slave?—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Killing the good believing Alderman, — but 'twas against my will.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Then I'me not so much oblig'd to thee, —but where's the money, the 8000 l. the Plate and Jewels, sirrah?

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Death the Dog has eat it.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Eat it! oh Lord, eat 8000 l. wou'd I might never come out of this Basket alive, if ever I made such a meal in my life.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Ye Dog you have eat it, and I'le make ye swallow all the Doses you writ in your Bill, but I'le have it upward or downward. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Hah, one of the Rogues my Doctours.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Oh dear Sir, hang me out of the way rather.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Madam, I have sent away the Basket to Mr. VVittmores Lodgings.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p:
You might have sav'd your self that labour, I now having no more to doe, but to bury the stinking Corps of my
quondam Cuckold, dismiss his Daughters, and give thee quiet possession of all.
To Witt.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Fair Lady, you'l take me along with you? Snaps.

div.stage: Pulls off his Hat and comes up to her.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: My Husband! — I'me betray'd—

sp.speaker: Sir. Pat.
sp.p: Husband! I do defie thee Satan, thou greater Whore than she of Babylon: thou shame, thou abomination to thy Sex.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Rail on, whilst I dispose my self to laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
Leander, call all the House in, to be a witness of our Divorce.
Ex. Leander.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: Do, and all the World, and let 'em know the Reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Methinks I find an inclination to swear, —to curse my self and thee, that I cou'd no better discern thee; nay, I'me so chang'd from what I was, that I think I cou'd even approve of Monarchy and Church Discipline, I'me so truly convinc'd I have been a beast and an ass all my life.

div.stage: Enter La. Know. Isabella, Lucre. Lean. Lodwick, Fan. &c.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: Hah, Sir Patient not dead?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, take notice that I am a Cuckold, a Crop-ear'd snivelling Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Cuckold! sweet Sir, shaw that's a small matter in a man of your Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p:
And I beg your pardon Madam, for being angry that you call'd me so. [To La. Know.] And yours, Dear Isabella, for desiring you to marry my good Friend there [points to Witt.] whose Name I perceive I was mistaken in: — And yours Leander, that I wou'd not take your Advice long since: And yours fair Lady, for believing you honest, — twas done like a credulous Coxcomb: — And yours Sir, for taking any of your Tribe for Wise, Learn'd, or Honest.
To Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I deceiv'd ye onely to serve my Friend, and Sir, your Daughter is married to Mr. Knowell; your Wife had all my stock of Love before, Sir. Lod. and Isab. kneel.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Why God-a-mercy—some comfort that,—God bless ye—I shall love disobedience while I live for't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'me glad on't Sir, for then I hope you will forgive Leander, who has married my Sister and not my Mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: How! has he serv'd me so,—I'le make him my Heir for't; thou hast made a Man of me my Boy, and faith we will be merry,—fair Lady, you may depart in peace fair Lady, restoring my Money, my Plate, my Jewels and my Writings, fair Lady—.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: You gave me no Money Sir, prove it if you can, and for your Land, 'twas not settled with this Proviso, If she be Honest?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: 'Tis well thou dost confess I am a Cuckold, for I wou'd have it known, fair Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Fa.
sp.p: 'Twas to that End I married you, good Alderman.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I'faith I think thou didst sweet-heart, I'faith I think thou didst.

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: Right Sir, for we have long been Lovers, but want of Fortune made us contrive how to marry her to your good Worship. Many a wealthy Citizen Sir, has contributed to the maintenance of a younger Brother's Mistress, and you are not the first Man in Office that has been a Cuckold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: Some comfort that too, the Brethren of the Chain cannot laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
A very pleasant old Fellow this faith, I cou'd be very merry with him now but that I am damnable sad, —Madam, I shall desire to lay the Saddle on the right Horse.
To La. Know.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Onely Madam, if I were as some men are, I should not be as I am.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: It may be so Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I say no more, but matters are not carry'd so swimmingly, but I can dive into the meaning on't.

div.stage: Sir Patient talks this while to Lodw.

sp.speaker: La. Kn.
sp.p: I hate this Hypothetical way of arguing, answer me Categorically.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Hypothetical and Categorical! what does she mean now? [Aside.] — Madam, in plain English I am made a Iohn A-Nokes of, Iack-hold-my-staff, a Merry Andrew Doctor to give Leander time to marry your Daughter, and 'twas therefore I was hoisted up in the Basket,—but as the Play says, 'tis well 'tis no worse: I'de rather lose my Mistress then my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: But how came this Rascal Turboon to admit you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: For the lucre of our fees Sir, which was his recompence.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.p: I forgive it you, and will turn Spark, they live the merriest lives—keep some City Mistress, go to Court, and hate all Conventicles.
sp.l: You see what a fine City Wife can doe
Of the true breed: Instruct her Husband too:
I wish all civil Cuckolds in the Nation,
Would take Example by my Reformation.

div.head: EPILOGUE, spoken by Mrs. Gwin.
div.l: I Here, and there, o'reheard a Coxcomb Cry Looking about.
Ah, Rott it—'tis a Womans Comedy,
One, who because she lately chanc't to please us,
With her Damn'd stuff will never cease to teaze us.
What has poor Woman done that she must be,
Debar'd from Sense and Sacred Poetrie?
Why in this Age has Heaven allow'd you more,
And Women less of Wit then heretofore?
We once were fam'd in Story, and cou'd write
Equall to men; cou'd Govern, nay cou'd Fight.
We still have passive Valour, and can show
Wou'd Custom give us leave the Active too,
Since we no provocations want from you.
For who but we, cou'd your Dull Fopperies bear,
Your Saucy Love, and your brisk Nonsence hear;
Indure your worse then womanish affectation,
Which renders you the Nusance of the Nation;
Scorn'd even by all the Misses of the Town,
A sest to Vizard Mask, the Pitt-Buffoone;
A Glass by which th' admiring Country Fool
May learn to dress himself en Ridicule:
Both striving who shall most Ingenious grow
In Lewdness, Foppery, Nonsence, Noise and Show.
And yet to these fine things we must submit
Our Reason, Arms, our Lawrells, and our Wit.
Because we do not Laugh at you when Lewd,
And scorn and cudgell ye when you are Rude;
That we have Nobler Souls then you, we prove,
By how much more we're sensible of Love;
Quickest in finding all the subtlest waies
To make your Ioys: why not to make you Plays?
We best can find your Feables, know our own,
And Gilts and Cuckolds now best please the Town;
Your way of writing's out of Fashion grown.
Method, and Rule — you only understand,
Pursue that way of Fooling, and be Damn'd.
Your Learned Cant of Action, Time, and Place,
Must all give way to the unlabour'd farce.
To all the Men of Witt we will subscribe:
But for you half Wits, you unthinking Tribe,
We'll let you see, what e're besides we doe,
How Artfully we Copy some of you:
And if you're drawn to th' life, pray tell me then
Why Women should not write as well as Men.
